sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But Endymion,
Prithee sweet lad, let me entreat a courtesy,
What countryman are you?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: What countryman?
An English man I take it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: An English man?
I rather think thou art a Russian
Thou carriest such a winter in thy breast.
How canst thou suffer such a winning beauty
To stand neglected? without a salutation?
Go to, you shamefaced fool, go kiss her, go.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: How kiss her? it does not become a servant
To be so saucy with his master's love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It rather not becomes Endymion,
A youth of that same mould and symmetry
To be so bashful 'fore a gentlewoman:
As for thy master I disclaim his love
As one unworthy.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: How? disclaim his love?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And with his love, all the whole world of men,
Except 'Be thee my soul: why fliest thou me?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come on, come on you little frozen-nothing,
I think we must be fain to make you take
Your love potion in a horn, you are so skittish.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Nay but Placenta. —Placenta holds his hands whiles Pandoura kisses him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O most redolent!
Aurora's spiced bed is not more sweet,
Not all the odours of the early East.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: You do but mock me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? but mock thee sweet?
By all the Cupids in thy face, I love thee
Beyond th' expression of a woman's tongue.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: This was that simple one that could not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: By this same nest of kisses I protest —
What wouldst thou more?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: More of your protestations.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But canst thou love me then?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Indeed fair lady
I do not know, I am but newly entered
Into this loving trade.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: You are a wag:
Take her by th' hand and strain it gently, so. —
Now kiss her fan and sigh. — good, excellent.
(Well I have seen some gallants in my days,
Though 'twas my fortune to be married,
To that same lob my husband, but no matter;)
Fie on this modesty, 'tis out of fashion,
Give her a green gown quickly, she will thank you.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Will not as much satin of the same colour
To make her one do as well?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come, you're a fool;
Down with her, she will discard you else,
As bashful, and unfit for lady's service. —[Pandoura slips down and pulls him after her.]

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ay me! what mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why there, why so; —
O for Neander now and Lucius
To view this spectacle, this would crack that great
That strong and mighty bond of friendship, and
Make them both quarrel for her: nay Endymion,
As she did pluck you down, so 'tis your office
To take her up, else she'll forget herself
Good soul, and slumber there eternally. —

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now fie upon you sir, you've spoiled my linen.
Pray heavens nobody saw us: good Placenta
Re-edify what is amiss.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: All's well,
all's well, save only here does want a pin.
But stay I'll furnish you. —
Yes, here's a knot molested too. —

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Fair sir,
This may seem lightness in me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Rather gravity
Who naturally tend downward thus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But sir,
Let me entreat you for to entertain
A better faith of her that is your servant,
Give it the right name sir, and call it love.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: I'll call it what you please fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He never thinks of's master: well this boy,
Must we train farther with us till we meet
With our two icy lovers. Come Pandora
Will you entreat your fairest paramour
T'accompany us into the grove? we may
Perchance there meet his master, whom he seeks.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sweet shall I crave?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Not where you may command

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: So, so, I'll now go plant this billing coupleExeunt Pan. Endym.
Under some pleasant tree, which done I'll go
And range the fields for Lucius and Neander,
And bring them to behold their close embraces,
This certainly will make them hungry, and bite,
Waken their dull and sleepy appetite,
We never prize ought truly, think it dear,
Until the time of parting does draw near. —Exit.

div.head: The song.
div.l: To the ladies, joy, delight,
And a servant that dares fight;
No need of painting, but a face
With perpetuity of grace.
To the lords a gracious eye
If they have a mistress by.
To them both, more than all this,
Their prince's happiness, and bliss.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The day's our own, we have the sun, the wind,
And all that can be called advantages, bear up.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: As I'm a gentleman, and an elder brother —

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: St, not a word.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: You wrong me sir, I will swear out my swear, as
I am a gentleman I must, and will swear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay sweet master mongrel
Mistake me not, I do not go about,
For to deprive you of that ornament,
That fashionable quality: I but entreat you,
For to be frugal in your language, and,
To husband your lungs; you have an enemy
That will require them all, had you more oaths.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: How? Do you think I have no more? by my —

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: O, hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Nay, you shall hear me, by —Ante. stops his mouth.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: By my — by — my indad la.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: By my indad la, you'll spoil all, why you'll spend
All before the time. But see your adversaries are at hand.
This is their captain, their conductor. Love. Stay. Enter Loveall. and pulls out his watch.
I've hit the very punto, this same minute,
Does cut the hour into two equal portions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You that are grown a time-observer, you
With that fine pocket Saturn in your hand;
Look this way.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But are these your champions?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They are my conquerors, if you please: but where are your employments?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: They'll be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more. Love-all, please you to take notice
Of these gentlemen, they are of rank, and my friends.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sweet sir, my only wish is that my fortunes were but of growth, to show in what degree of honour, I hold any whom you shall vouchsafe to call a friend. — I thirst to know you sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do not swear yet.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay as you please.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Sir I desire you to pardon me, I must not swear yet, my general will give the word when I must vent.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: 'Tis no great matter, if you throw away Cudnig●,
Or beswiggers, or some such innocent oath upon him.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Say you so? [the scholar offers to salute Loveall who regards him not]

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: When will he come towards me?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sir may I know your name?

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.p: My name sir? why sir? I am not ashamed of my name sir. My name is sir m. Mung. Sir. A poor elder brother sir. And yet not very poor neither sir. Heir to six, or seven hundred a year sir. My father is a gentleman sir. I have an uncle that is a justice of peace sir. I can borrow his white mare when I please sir. She stood him in thirty pieces sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: A mongrel sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Only be sure you be not dashed.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Ashamed of your name, say you? You come of a very great house, I'll assure you; I know many of the mongrels that are able to dispend, yearly, more than I am willing to speak of at this time; and which keep their sons as gentlemanlike, at the inns o'th court with as good clothes on their backs, as rich belts, and as fair guilt rapiers, as the best gentlemen o'the land sir — oh well said, come lift up bravely now.

div.head: Act. 3. Sce 2.
div.stage: Anter. Noddle-empty. Love. Will wiseacres. Hamershin. Mr. mongrel.

sp.speaker: Anter.
sp.p: 'Tis a hundred to nothing, but these are they, look to your standing, and be sure you suffer him to offer first; you have the more advantage.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Let me alone, if I do not utterly confound him, let me never wear good suit of clothes more, I have not read the Arcadia for nothing.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Anteros, a couple of friends of mine.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Sir I shall count myself fortunate in their acquaintance; sweet sir — worthy sir.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Sans compliment monsieur, je suis, vostre tres-humble varlet.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: There's one of his parcels gone, he has but three more in all the world.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Signior mio molto honorifico, per testa deal mio padre, io non he altro, advffirirui, che me stesso, però fate capital di me, è splendetemi per quel chio vaglio.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Does he speak French sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: How think you sir?

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Nay but well I mean?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: O admirably, take heed what you do, he's a great traveller I tell you.

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: God's me! is he so? I'll not meddle with him then, I would have tickled him else.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Signior, io mi terrei ricco s' io hanessi solamente le decime de i vostri favori.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p:
Nay sir I am not so well skilled in the language, as I
could wish I were, for your sake, I can speak a little sir, un peu, monsieur, tellement quellement.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: May I be so bold as to bear your name sir?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: My name is Nodale empty sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: An inns o'the court man sir?

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: I have pissed in some green pots in my day's sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wis. My name is William wiseacres sir. I am of a sanguine complexion.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Very melancholy sometimes sir. He offers to feel him by the nose end.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Like enough sir

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ha, he, he, he —

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he, — oh my sides —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: God's my life! I should lose it all were my patrimony laid on't. Come on sir, brace me your invention to the height, you see your antagonist.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: To him, ferret him, ferret him.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Noble sir may I be so ambitious, as to desire my name, to be enrolled in the catalogue of your well wishers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I do honour the very shadow of your shoe strings.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Your mocked sir, he wears boots.

sp.speaker: Hamm.
sp.p: And am wholly yours cap a pea.

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Pox on 't, I made full account, to have had that next myself, how came he by it trow?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What say you sir?

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: I say sir, that it is your best course, to take heed how you make a deed of gift of yourself, for fear some of your friends suffer for it, for the physiognomy of your boot, tells me, it was never made for you, I do not think but you borrowed them.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And I say sir, that it is better to borrow then to take upon trust, and never pay, as many such gallants as you do.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Love-all, this heat is done, let's rub, and walk.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Agreed, master empty, take some pity on the scholar, let him breath a little, wilt please you walk? Lovell and Nod walk. Ant. and Ham. walk.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well done, 'twas smartly followed; but let's walk;

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ha, I don't think never go law, but I have seen you somewhere .

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You're beholding to your eyes for that.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Love-all, look, look, look, another heat.

sp.speaker: Vvise.
sp.p: Don't you use sometimes about Stamford side?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have hunted, and hawked, thereabouts sir in my days, and been in Sara's here too sir, I was at the last horse race, sir, when velvet-heels, and currants run sir, I have some reason to remember it, I am sure, I was cheated of twenty pieces there, I'll swear unto you sir as I'm a gentleman, and an elder brother, I'm a very fool —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Out you nullifidian, don't let the gentleman swear, take't upon his bare word.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Nay sir, I'll believe you without swearing.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay but conceive me sir. I was a very fool (As I said before) to be drawn in after that manner, I would fain see the best cheater of them all, gull me of so much now.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Well sir, I desire your better acquaintance. I have the best wine in town for you, please you to accept.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Thank you sir. [they shake hands, he feels him by the nose end.]

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I think you and I are much upon a complexion. He, he, he, you have lost your maidenhead. If it please you sir to come to my lodging sir, when you come to London, I shall think myself very much bound to you, I have some pretty books there to lend you, I have Aristotle's problems in English, and Albertus magnus de secretis, ay, as I am a living soul.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Let's take 'em off. [they part, Lou. walks with Wis. Ant. with Mun.]

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Troth sir you have a very neat suit there, I am much taken with the proportion of your hose, 'tis a deep French sir. I have a satin suit to make shortly, and I would bestow, some twenty dozen of gold lace upon it, if I could but purchase the knowledge of such a tailor as yours, I should think myself beholding to my stars for it.

sp.speaker: Ante,
sp.p: O your walking faculty, it is the only thing, now adays your gentlemen practise.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Indeed sir, I think it be time for you to seek out for a new one, for I think your old one will trust you no longer.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Should you but see them walk in Paul's, or in the temple, with what a ravishing garb — you would admire.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: He, he, you are such a merry man, but indeed I hold that tobacco is very good for phlegmatic complexions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your hilt a little forwarder; very good, your very rapier speaks French; I protest he shows in the graceful carriage of his leg, as though he had been a man of forty plays, fifteen moutings.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay, I shall do well in time.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: God's me! you have stained your cloak sir, how will you do? I doubt the gentleman that lent you it will be angry.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, there's no remedy, I must go and relieve my scholar. — sir, a word in private, do you know that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have read Overbury's characters; he is a silly fellow in black, I take it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well sir, however you disesteem him, I could wish you would take heed of him; I wonder he did not strike you all this while. Go to, I say no more, I hold him to be the stoutest man of his hands in all this side o'th country.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Is he so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why he is sent for far and near by the valiant of the parishes, to play matches at football: I tell you he is the only hammershin this shire can boast of; not a servingman can keep a leg or an arm whole for him, he has a pension from all the surgeons within the compass of forty miles, for breaking of bones.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nay for my part sir, let him be as tall a man as he will, I do not care a 〈◊〉 for him, (Do you see) for I do not mean to quarrel with him, only I make account to jeer him a little.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, take heed, say I.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nay sir, I'll take your counsel, I'll go and fetch my rapier I left within, and then let him do his worst. Ex. Nod.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Follow him, follow him, the exalted mushroom — a whoreson butterfly, he has nothing to jeer you for but your borrowed cloak and boots; and I don't think but they be your own for all his talking.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No indeed, to tell you the truth, I borrowed them of a bachelor of our house, mine own lie in limbo at a barber's shop for tobacco.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But why dost not beat him man? God's me! beat him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Nay, I would have been at him, but that I was afraid —
they say many of 'em are very desperate fellows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, to do them right, there be many of 'em that have run through the discipline of a bawdy-house, and learned to quarrel there, and have seen the entrails of a fence-school too, and in one word are sufficiently valiant; but that proves not a generality. There are of them (I'll warrant you) as there are of your scholars, some that wear swords, only to scare fools.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay sir, I would have you to know, that I am neither afraid of him, nor his sword: but I would not willingly die yet, if I could help it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fear 't not man, thou shalt live I warrant thee, to see thy good name buried before thee. Have you nothing about you to strike him with?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Yes, I have the key of my study door in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O nothing better than that, follow him, to him, to him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Shall I, i' faith? shall I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never stand, shall I? shall I? but do 't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Never go, and so I will: I'll teach him to abuse any of our cloth again. Exit Ham. He whispers him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St, Mr. mongrel.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: As I'm a gentleman, and an elder brother —

div.stage: He runs after them offering to draw.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: But how now Anteros? what business is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you but hold your peace, and follow them
With your sweet William? nay, but will you go? Ex. love. And William
You'll lose the banquet if not presently.

sp.speaker: Anter.
sp.l: O, o. —
Would I could lose myself, become a mouse,
Or fly, that I might find a cabin here,
To hide myself from these same women. O, —He climbs the tree.
But I will climb this tree —

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I wonder much
Where our two loving friends should lie so close;
There's not a place where they do use, but we
Have visited this morning. I do long
To give them this most pleasing spectacle:
But I will now search the justice his house,
perchance they may be there.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Endymion,Exit Pla.
Another kiss; lo thus I will revengeShe kisses Endym.
Myself on those two frozen lovers; thus,
And thus, and thus — revenge, how sweet thou art
Unto a woman!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O — I am afraid
They will offend, commit, commit before me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And canst thou love me, sweet Endymion?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Behold a taste what I can do.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: These kissesHe kisses her redit in scenan Pla.
Have not that masculine relish yet methinks ,
Which I enjoyed in the manly embraces
Of Lucius, or Neander.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: It is strange,
Not one about this house that can instruct me
What should become of them, I wonder at it;
But I am glad that Constantina's flight
Is not suspected yet, so well that boy
Does personate her.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Are they not there Placenta?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: St; no. O yes your uncle is at home.
It will not yet be dinner time this hour;
You may embrace another walk.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Content;
Endymion, wil't please you to accompany us? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why so then — what again?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: You'll leave your blubbering, minion, come your ways.
You set your mind on such a man? yet more?
You might as well be in love with that same sun,
And should as soon enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He speaks high,
Pray heavens he does not look so high, for fear
He should descry me.

sp.speaker: Vrse.
sp.l: Father, I cannot last
Out two days longer without Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How's that? now all my stars be merciful!
It is a vision sure, this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come, you're a foolish girl, he marry you?
That day that he does marry you, will I
Bring back to life all that were dead before
The universal deluge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, I'll help
You with a far better expression, sir,
that day that he does marry her, shall you
Become an honest man; a harder province
Than to bring all the dead, to life again.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: There are a hundred reasons (Daughter) why
You should not hope it, first he hates all women,
Next if he did not, you that are deformed,
Lame, and mishapen, black, besides, ill mannered. —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: (He does not see the wallet on her back.)
Have the least cause to hope.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: But there are (Father)
Six hundred reasons, why I should love him.
His manly carriage, his full breasts, his hair,
And his fine clothes, his golden breeches, and —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His traitorous nose: ay, ay, 'tis that I know,
'Tis like the ivy-bush unto a tavern,
Which tells us there is wine within; but I
Will take an order with you sir e'er long,
And have you pared.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Well I will never leave
My crying (That's resolved) until I see him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O! could I commit a crime ere I was made,
'Gainst nature worthy such a punishment?
It is decreed, I will unman myself, immediately.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: What shall I do? 'tis strange —
Well, 't must be so: I will go seek Terpander,
And move him to this match: most of his lands
I have in mortgage, nay indeed they are
Forfeited to me, for the day is passed
Wherein he was bound to pay in the money,
The advantage of this forfeiture, will I
Threaten to take, unless he does compel,
His son to take my daughter, to his wife.
Nay, rather than I will be disappointed,
He for a portion, shall have in his bonds,
Come daughter, be of comfort, we will go
Directly to Terpander, where I'll use
Such arguments, as shall enforce him make
His son both love, and marry you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Like enough.
'Tis very likely sir, but that this tree
Does not afford any such fruit, I'd throwHe comes down.
An old shoe after you, — such arguments
as shall enforce him make his son, both love,
And marry you — well how his pills may work
Which the old man, I know not: for myself
I will provide a quick deliverance.
Why shepherd? Stipes? [tic toc:]now I must, and will
Go forward in this plot, of my disguise.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What make you there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why nothing Jack.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come on, you are a fine fellow, to go and set them together by the ears thus, are you not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But have they done it finely?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Finely do you call it? why your scholar has so mauled Mr. noddle with the key of his study door, made such a breach in his pericranium, that without question all his French ends have taken their flight, through that passage; as for my cousin Mr. William, he's crept into an old hole, behind the hangings, that in the days of old, has been the Asylum, for decayed boots, and shoes out of date, and there lies he, all alone, very melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, but how was my gentleman, and my elder brother employed all this while?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: As gentlemen use now adays, in swearing; when he saw that he could not draw his sword, he ran up and down the room, and measured out the time of the combat with oaths.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Death! that I had but seen this.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Would thou hadst: for I have e'en taken a surfer of them. I pray thee let's invent some way, or other
For to be rid of them, canst thou not think?
Think, think, man — think — which I'll effect, unless
All that is called fortune, doth forsake me.
Seest thou that brace of cabins, on each side
My uncle's house?

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: They're dog-kennels I take it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: They are, no more, but see they come, I'll slip
Aside lest I be seen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wonder what
His brain is now so hot in travail with.

div.head: Act. 3. Sce. 6.
div.stage: Ant. love. Wise. noddle empty, with his head, and face all bloody.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Lend me your hankercher, if you have one about you cousin, mine has not a dry place in it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What do you bleed Mr. noddle?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes sir a little wild blood, hold that cousin, un peu monsieur.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Did not you tell me, all his French ends were gone? un peu will not forsake him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: A whoreson cowardly slave, to strike a man e'er one was aware of him, and to give one no time, to draw his rapier —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Sme, 'tis somewhat deep I doubt.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nothing by Hercules' sir, a scratch, a scratch, well I'll say nothing, but by this good blood, that runs —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith if you had done as that good blood does, Mr. noddle, it had been better for you.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: No sir, I scorn it, I am not of that strain i'faith, and that he shall know, the sempiternal rascal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on Mr. wiseacres, I believe you and your kinsman are much of a complexion.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I am very melancholy at this time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I but you must take heed of these fits, they'll spoil you, I heard say, that you crept into a private, retired room e'en now, and there conversed with spiders and crickets, fie upon it, you must labour against that humour; but indeed methinks your cousin is of a very deep sanguine.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ha, he, you are such a witty man.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Cousin? Yes I am much beholding to my cousin; I might have been killed for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, come, I like him well for it, the gentleman does weigh how much the Republ. might be impeached, by the loss of a man.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Republic? Repuddingpy. By this light, a man is little better than mad, that will keep company with such snow-heaps, such white-livered, counterfied jackdaws — but all's one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ay, I betwixt friends, and kinsmen; ye two are all one I know. Your cousin is very choleric now.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I but I am very seldom so, for Albertus Magnus' faith —[Loveall as though he came from his uncles.]

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Now the good gods! where shall I find these most unfortunate gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why how now Jack? what inauspicious wind
Has raised this cloudy weather in thy face?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O Anteros, we are undone, undone;
I'll have this day wear black ith' calendar,
That after ages may beware of it,
It is so full of omen —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's the matter? I pray thee speak. He feigns to hear somebody coming.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: O they be here, — who's there?
Pray heavens it be not the constable's officious industry: how will you do sir? You have slain the scholar.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: I would I had else.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay sir, this is neither time nor place for such idle wishes, here has been a surgeon already, that lives hard by, and his sentence is, that he cannot live above two hours, he swooned six times since you left him, it seems you bruised him so with falling on him, with the hilt of your rapier, that he bleeds inward — I know not what to say to it — I was bewitched I think, nay think, think, think what course you will take, you must be sudden, the officers are sent for to apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is this in jest (I wonder) or in earnest?

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Is he so indeed? I pray you tell me true sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Why, what do you take me to be sir? have I this for my love, and care of your safety? as you sowed, so reap for me; I hope you will believe your own senses, I think I see the officers coming.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: 'Sme! what shall I do? Mr. Loveall, nay good sir, I do believe you, I know not which way to take.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay there's no stirring that way, you'll meet them in the teeth.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: What if I go through the back door, and take horse?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: They'll meet you that way too.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Any thing, good sir, I beseech you, look the door goes, I protest twenty sergeants could not have struck such a fear into me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, will you trust your fortunes into my hands?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: And lives sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Quickly then enter here, I'll shut you in until the search be passed: nay will you in? who's there? immediately, good master William. He shuts Nod. into one of them.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Nay sir, I'll go to my horse if there were twenty constables, they have nothing to do with me, for I am sure I did not strike a blow, no as I'm a living soul. —

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: God's me, what will you do? were not you in the company with him? that makes you accessary; have you read so much law, and know not that? nay, will you in? — ha, ha, he.

div.stage: He puts him into the other.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What sayest thou now my Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What say I?
I say thou art an arch-dissembler,
A workman in the trade: by all that's good,
I should have been thus gulled myself, thou didst
So smoothly act it, with such passion,
And anger at their incredulity.
I was afraid thou wouldst have beat the fool,
Because he would not let himself be gulled
So soon as thou wouldst have him, but stay now —
How shall we dress our other brace?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: That province
Is yours; as for mine own, you see I have
Provided for them, and conveniently:
Yet if you will embrace my counsel, write
After the copy I have set you, do,
Behold a pattern, and see (Happily)
A chest where Stipes in the days of old
Has kept tame coneys, now uninhabited.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Right, but I fear, 'tis not capacious
Enough for both.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing, look you here,
See you that fine spruce new erected hogsty
On the other side of Stipes house?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And do you see it may be pinned without?
Hist, easily, softly, I'll fill up the timeThey enter.
With some discourse, till you have framed your countenance.

div.head: Act. 3. Scen. 8.
div.stage: Love. Antemr. mr. Mung. sir Hammer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Would I might never stir Mr. mongrel, if I care a pin for a hundred such, an inns oth' court man quoth 'a? ne'er go, I think they learn nothing there, but how to swagger, and be proud.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay sir, now I must chide you, will you accuse all, for the default of some particulars? by the same reason, I'll conclude, that all ye scholars, are coxcombs, because I see one that is so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Meaning me sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Meaning you sir? pardon me 'tis mere injustice in you, I'll assure you sir, this whole realm, yields not better qualified gentlemen, and more gentilely parted, than many of them are, and to whom, the common weal is more indebted.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Because he has got a good suit of clothes upon his back (I'll be hanged if they be paid for yet) and a ring in is band string, to play withal when he wants discourse, he thinks he may carry the ball on is toe before him, and that no man must dare to meet him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No more scholar, you have met with him sufficiently, why Anteros, when? and here's a brave Pylades too, that would not see his Orestes oppressed by multitude. [he claps him on the back.]

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Arrest me sir? soft, and easily sir, more words to a bargain; s'duds! I think my sword be mortised into a snail,[he flies back and offers to draw]I cannot entreat him out of his shell. Arrest me sir? As I'm a gentleman, and an elder brother, I owe no man a farthing that I mean to pay him. Nay come sir, I am fleshed now i'faith.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You will not quarrel with your friend's sir, will you?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Friend's sir? I know not whether you be my friend, or no; I am sure you use no friendly language.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prithee scholar, tail off Mr. mongrel a little, he'll never leave now he has drawn blood once.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Come, you're a fool; the gentleman's of worth, and our friend.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.p: Nay I have done now, I did but try how I could quarrel a little.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Faith sir, this would have made a fair show in a country alehouse.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay sir, as soon as my father dies, (Which will not be long I hope, for he lies sick now) I'll go to London, and learn to quarrel there, for a year or two, and then come down again, and practise amongst my tenants.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why Anteros; pray thee relieve me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St, not a word, for a million of worlds. Hark you scholar. [he whispers with the scholar.]

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I hope you are not angry?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Angry old bully? he had a hard heart, that would be angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you, his wound has been searched by a very skilful surgeon, and his pia mater is found to be perished, and when that's gone, you know there is small hope.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: None at all sir, I've read it in Magirus, cousin mongrel, come hither quickly —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now, now, how greedily the scholar sucks it in.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: What's the matter? but is this true?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As true as you're a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: He never emptied a buttery pot after a match at football, with greater appetite, than he devours this gullery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Take heed what you do, the least protraction is full of danger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: O the lord! what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Loveall stir the door a little — passion oh me! there's somebody at the door, look, look, creep into this chest, I'll shut you in. He shuts up the scholar.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: anywhere good sir.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Where will you hide me sir? I'll go into the chest too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Here's hardly room enough for myself.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Stay, stay, stay. In good sooth Mr. Constable here's no such men this way — what say you, you threepenny crack crown? I tell you, they have already taken horse. Here, here, here, creep in, stoop man, stoop. [he shuts mun. into the hogsty.]

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Why so, we're now at liberty, farewell.
My sister's wrongs, and sorrows call for me,
And shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well adieu sweet sir. Exit.
I must be sudden, or I'm lost for ever. [tic. toc.]
By this time sure my father melts (Why shepherd.)
The ample benefit, that shall acrew
unto him by this worthy match, this instant
Arrives at is weather-beaten apprehension;
(I do but know it, am but sure of it)
O, what a dainty pleasant thing it is
For to be free from care! to sleep a night,
Without the dreaming of a creditor,
Or the disturbance of that gobbling forfeit!
It cannot but be so, upon my soul,
He trades in this same cogitation,
This very minute — Stipes. che ti venga l' cancro.
Well, if he be above ground, I will find him,
Or lose myself, I'll seek him in the pastures. Exit.

div.head: The song, sung by two trebles.

sp.speaker: 1. Treb.
sp.l: But why
Do the winged minutes fly
So fast away?
Stop your course ye hasty hours,
And solicit all the powers
To let you stay.
For the earth could never show forth
An object of a greater worth.

sp.speaker: 2. Treb.
sp.l: But why
Do the winged minutes fly
So fast away?

sp.speaker: 1. Treb.
sp.l: It is because that they which follow,
Crowd on to have a sight as well as they;

sp.speaker: 2. Treb.
sp.l: Hark how the ghosts of passed moments groan,
'Cause they are gone:
And rail at fate,
And curse the date
Of their short lives expired so soon.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Then stop your course, you hasty hours,
And solicit all the powers
To let you stay,
For the earth could never show forth
An object of a greater worth.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena 1.
div.l: Ha, ha, he,
I have discovered more than e'er Columbus,
Or our own waterfowl, drake: my pretty stripling,
Which I did take away from Stipes even now,
Is proved a woman, proved an errant lady,
That is in quest after her errant knight,
Who is enchanted. 'tis the niece (Forsooth)
Of our good virtuous justice, mr.hook,
Who has put on this habit for to follow
Her lover Cleopes, who has forsook her.
All this did she confess to me in private,
'Soon as she saw I had descried her sex
And name; but I have stayed her pilgrimage,
She's fast enough, I warrant her, i'th noose
Of wedlock now, to stir in haste. No sooner
Did I read woman in her looks, but straight
I did command my maids for to unpage her,
And cook her in her kind, in her own sauce;
She's pickled now in some three yards of lawn:
Here she has it, and there she has it, fie, fie.
Was I a young man now again, and should
Venture on such a dish to carve, by'r lady,
I should not know which side for to begin on:
Hardly distinguish breast from back. Well, well, —
Beshrew my heart the queans, where'er they had them,
Have hung good rags about her; sure they borrowed them.
This being done, I went unto Neander,
Told him, that I had got a boy, and dressed him
Fit for his palate: he rejoiced, made haste
Unto the contract, and (As kind fortune would)
That very time a good old merry vicar
Of my acquaintance came to visit me.
I craved his aid, and (In one word) I brought her
Veiled, but first softened by a thousand threatenings,
If she but moved towards a discovery.
The good kind gentleman thinking her boy,
And therefore in his power when ere he please
for to untie the knot, is before witness,
Contracted to her by the vicar. — o for Lucius now.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: See where he comes; but yet how heavily!
How full of earth methinks his paces be!
He looks as though his teeth had played this fortnight,
Kept holiday. But I'll accost him. — Lucius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The gods befriend thee, whosoever thou art,
That I am thought worth naming yet, not lost
Unto all mankind quite, though to myself!

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: These words do savour of too much distraction.
You must take comfort sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who is that dares talk
Of comfort to me? But once name the word
That is exiled whole nature? good mr.lively
Wast you that spoke?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: It was, and I must have you
Remove this same December from your looks:
I come to make you happy.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.l: Thou art come
To lose thy labour then; I am below
Both all the love, and all the spite of fortune,
She will not make me happy, and she cannot
Make me more wretched than I am. I lie,
She may do both. But speak thou reverend head,
Has ought that is good befallen my Neander,
That thou dar'st venture out that name of happy
So confidently upon me? — say.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: There has,
But more to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Good, happiness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How? happiness to me? thou shouldst have put
The space of fifteen ages 'twixt those words,
They are so far from reconciliation;
Thou hast no grammar in thee, knowest no concord.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: But I have music in me, and that's better.
I'll make thee dance my solitary one.
Pandora shall be thine today.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How? mine today?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Thy wife, thy self, but in another character.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Unspeak't again, it must not be.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: It must.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dost thou intend to buy me to thee? and
To break me and my fortunes with a courtesy,
Which I shall never be able to repay?
Employ thy art then, all thy quicker plots
To further my Neander in his love:
Who by how much the more his virtues be
Greater than mine (Who hardly have so much
As will redeem me from the name of vicious)
So much the more will apprehend the benefit,
So much the more reward thee.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Speak no further,
Pandora's thine, she's thine, thine own, believe't.
He is already married to another.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I do confess that I am something fallen
Oft from that height of reason which before,
While I had liberty, I did enjoy:
But thou dost wrong me much, if thou dost think
That love has eaten up all man in me.
I tell you, I do know your plots, your drifts,
And all your consultations, as well
As if I had had a cabin in your bosom,
And had from thence betrayed them; did not I
Hear when Neander did solicit thee
For to procure a masculine bride for him?
Did not I hear thee promise him to do it?
Hast thou not now performed it? are not they
By thy procurement now contracted? speak;
'Tis not so easy to deceive the eyes
Of love, howe'er our frantic poets say
He feeds on naught but lolium.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Lucius,
As I do hope to live, as I do prize
My lungs, my breath, laughter, and sack, (Believe me)
I have Neander fast, he is married
To one that is as truly woman, as
Was she that did produce thee, and because
You shall be certain of 't, 'tis Constantina.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But canst thou utter this (Without a blush?)
Or hath thy many years
Blocked up those channels of thy blood, that now
They are not able to afford that face,
(That starved face of thine, bankrupt of virtue)
The least relief? but I'll undo your plots.
Since you do force me, I'll confess a secret,
Which hitherto I've hardly whispered
unto my privat'st thoughts. I am no husband,
No husband (Mark you) for Pandora, nor
For any woman living; for kind nature
Has stamped eunuch on me from my cradle.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That which is true.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: An eunuch!

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 3.
div.stage: Liuely, Neander, Constantina velat â fancy, Lucius.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: But see Neander comes with his new bride.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Why do you weep and sigh so boy? no more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Do you hear that?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But see my Lucius.
I must quite alter my discourse, my garb,
And all my actions. Hence dull melancholy,
I now must find a face that must out-smile
A morn in June. Lucius, a thousand hails.

sp.speaker: Constan.
sp.l: Unhappy Constantina! to whom fate
Neither permits to live, nor yet to die.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Break off those sighs you peevish girl, or I'll — not yet?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What means this strange and ponderous eye?
As though you were to take our altitudes
Lucius? what? and do you smile? faith speak.
How dost thou like my choice? perhaps you wonder
At this so sudden match; but (Friend) you see
What love and a fair gentlewoman can do.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: I am the boldest wretch alive. It cannot,
Cannot be long before he needs must know her.
What will become of thee then lively? ha?
You must be sure not to unveil him sir,
The boy would not be known.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What muse you on
So deeply Lucius? does your first son's name
You shall beget on the most fair Pandora
Perplex you now? come on, I'll answer for you,
He shall be called fortunate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not so,
Rather that name belongs to you Neander,
That shall have no such care to trouble you:
For if my art deceives me not (Fair creature
Your hand) this wife of yours is never likely
For to bear children, but on her back, or arms.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Why pray thee sweet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Cause in this little vale
that lies at the foot of Venus' mountain, here,
I do discover something too much for mother.
Come, come, Neander, these are poor devices,
Tricks of the scene, and stale, they will not take.
And you grey hairs, methinks that thou shouldst owe
A greater and more filial reverence
To the fair ceremonies of the church, then thus
To stalk with them, to make them stales unto
Such base ridiculous —

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Lucius, do but hear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Here's a benefit
Placed most deservingly! I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I do not apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A fair gown
Indeed, and soap, and starch enough, to dazzle
The eyes of some young country heir, that has
Never been drilled through Drury lane, or Bloomsbury.
But pray thee (Friend) whose daughter hast thou married?
What may she have to name?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What shall I answer?
I am i'th briers.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Tell him 'tis Constantina
Our justice's niece.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Most excellent dissembler!
As though you know not Constantina sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this Constantina?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: 'Tis truer;
Somewhat than you do believe it is.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this
Jack Loveall's sister?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: 'Tis.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this she
Whom Cleopes once loved, and has forsaken?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O me! why do I live and hear that name?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Did you not mark that sigh? how smartly't came?
No, no, I have not fitted you, I have not.
'Tis a young Roscius I tell you. No sooner
Was Cleopes named, but the arch-villain sighed,
As if it had been truly Constantina.
I do not like this business yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this
That cried up wonder? that Fidelia?
A sudden change.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Yet at the last? 'tis well, I'll give the word
Unto Pandora: but with special care
that the boy knows not of his master's presence.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: What business is't that this same midwives face
Does fetch and carry thus about I wonder?
High, she appears again.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: All health old man.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Old? and how old? but what's the news that you
Are rigged with now? and whither bound I pray you?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Next to that loving pair of friends, whose sorrows
I have lamented oft, and amongst which
I judge it not the least, that while ye two
Discourse in sighs, and tears, that wanton maid
That is the cause of all your heaviness,
Lasciviously does sport herself, and melts
In the embraces of another.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Regardless of your woes, or her own honour.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Now all the gods! where is he?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Woman speak,
What is he for a man?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: I know him not,
So far as to his name; but this mine eyes
Dare witness, 'tis a composition
Of blood and spirits not to be despised.
A feature able enough to tempt; besides —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Neander, whilst we strive about the shadow
We have the substance ravished from us.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ha?
It cannot be, 'thas no affinity
With truth; it must not be believed good Lucius.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Can ye retire yourselves under this tree
A little, and expect? but ere I go,
Ye shall both promise as you're gentlemen
To endure the sight with patience.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: We will.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But does this woman gull us? Exit Plac.
Or is it real think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No more.

div.head: Act. 4. Sce 5.
div.stage: Placenta. Lucius. Pandoura. Neander, Endymion. Liuely. Constantina

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Can ye believe it yet? are your eyes yet
Instructed?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis my boy Endymion,
Now hell and tortures!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Were all odours lost,
And beggered nature had not sweets enough
To embalm the dying phoenix left, from hence
from this same lip, she might restore herself.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ah Lucius! must he not die?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Neander,
It is a sacrilege unpardonable
To pluck him from that altar.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Once more sweet —
Two pendant cherries when some gentle gale
Makes them to kiss, meet not with such a touch!

div.stage: [they both draw, and run at him, he saves himself behind Pandoura.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Villain, and traitor die.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: O me! my master. —

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: What do you mean? ah.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Alas. — sweet gentlemen. —She lays hold on Neander's arm.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Did all mankind inhabit in that breast,
I'd put the gods unto a second trouble
For to create that species a new.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Woman forbear.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: I do not like these tumults.
I'll get me home and drink a cup of sack.

sp.speaker: Paud.
sp.l: Neander, —
Lucius, —
Ah by that monster of my love, your friendship,
Lucius, by these eyes of mine, which thou
A thousand times and more haste dared to liken
Unto the brighter star of Venus, which
Is both the prologue and the epilogue
Unto the glorious sun: by thine own eyes
Which are two clearer stars, I do conjure thee
Forbear to prosecute such a revenge
Upon this innocent boy: for here I swear
By all those blessed powers, which know our thoughts,
I never loved him.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Most impudent woman,
Did not our eyes behold it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Neander,
Why do we stand thus coldly here? and not
How out a passage through this prostitute
To travail to the just destruction
Of her base lover, and my baser vassal?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Rather let all your fury end in me,
See here my naked breast employ your valours:
Why do you stand and gaze one on another?
What is the naked bosom of a virgin
A spectacle of such terror? if it be,
And that the fight of it hath cooled your bloods,
Then hear me speak: you Lucius may remember
That ancient stock of love, those many vows,
those many tears, those many longings, which
Have passed betwixt us: nor can you justly style it
A fault of mine, that time is now so old
And yet does see us two; but partly yours
Partly my father's nearness (For I must not
Give it the name it merits, covetousness)
Who seeing your so fervent love unto me,
Did strive to thrust me out with nothing, or
At least with such a portion, as you liked not;
Whilst thus I wavered, betwixt hope, and fear,
It fortuned, that this gentleman Neander
Became your rival ▪ who had not long been here,
Not long solicited, but I (Shame of women)
Began to love ye both, and which is more
I loved ye with an equal flame, (But see
What pageants Cupid can play!) it chanced
(Contrary to all men's expectations)
That by degrees such a strong tie of friendship
Did grow betwixt ye, that each of ye refused
(For his friend's sake) what then was proffered you,
My love; whilst I bewailed my miseries
Unto this midwife here, my friend, and grieved
At this my harder fortune — good PlacentaShe weeps.
Give them the rest.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Then take it in a word.
Supposing it the only way to win
One of you to her, I counselled her to feign
A love unto some other gentleman.
Whilst we were busy in these consultations,
As fortune would, your page Endymion
Came hither (Lucius) to seek his master.
We lay the train for him, she courts the boy,
And he (Poor lad) thinking her serious
Was caught immediately.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this true?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Would I could call it false — but otherwise
Than was expected hath it prospered. She weeps.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Placenta, ah Placenta.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Who's that calls me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Shall I disclose myself? I am ashamed. [they put up their swords.]

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: If it be so, Pandora, we crave pardon.
And do restore him life; but now(Fair soul)
If thou dost aim to reach a life so happy
so full of all content, that thou mayest fit
Within thy sphere (Like Venus) and look down
On all thy sex, and pity them; love this man.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Love this man. For as for myself I am
Already furnished with a mistress, see
My wife here — sweetest wife.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is this your wife?
I judge her happy who so e'er she is,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Believe him not, this is boy, a villain
(Whom I, but that —)

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Lucius forbear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dressed up
In woman's clothes by that same dotard lively.
Sweetest Neander leave.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: It is a woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By all the gods, it is a boy, 'tis false.
But for to rob you of all hope of me
Give me but care, I am an eunuch, if
You can endure to have a frozen statue,
Sleep by your side, whilst you awake, recount
The tedious minutes of your widowed nights
And sigh, and think, and think, and sigh again,
Behold an husband for you, I am he. She swoons.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O me! an eunuch?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Hold the gentlewoman
Ay me! she swoons, sweetest Pandora, ah.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ah good Lucius help,
She's gone — alas good heart. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But see she breathes again.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ah honey sweet
Pandora speak.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ah!
Hands off thou outside of a man; and thou
Uxorious creature, I do crave no aid
From you, forbear.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: How does my sweetest honey?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am not well Placenta, let us go
Into your house a while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Please you fair lady
To use my service?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? Your service sir?
You can do nothing, nor do I expect it.
But if your love towards me be worthy, lend me
Your page, but for an hour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: He is yours.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then sir adieu.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Shall I be vanquished thusPlac.
In friendship? But I will once more to lively. Plac.
And see what further counsel he will give me,Endym.
Fair wife let's go — rise up you villain boy;
Lucius' farewell.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What is he gone? so soon? Exit.
To's engineer I know, to his contriver;
but I will follow them so fast, that not
A syllable shall pass without my knowledge.
Stipes runs against Lucius.how now you rascal? where are your eyes I wonder?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: In as a good a headpiece as yours, I warrant you that, for all your fine clothes, sands, I think my penny as good silver as yours, every day i'th week, I'll tell you but so.

A maid of eighteen, to play with babes-clouts, well, 'tis no matter, let that pass though, go to, go to, 'tis an ill wind that blows nobody good, cry I, sure I rose o'th right side today, I shall have a servant by and by, and a lusty knave too, and here's the chincke, the chincke; as I was getting this rod even now, for my wise daughter, comes me Terpander's son, the angry boy, the smoke of tobacco, the whoreson which could not endure his mother, sdnds I was afraid at first to see myself alone with him, he did so stare with's rolling eyes, and 'twas no force by'r lady, for I had five good shillings in my purse; but he to put me out of doubt salutes me most lovingly, as thus, Stipes God save you, save you Stipes — no, Stipes God save you — Stipes be hanged — a blockhead, sdnds i doubt I should make but a scurvy gentleman, I want the trick on't. — but let that pass though, I have the money here, and presently, my man will come, which Anteros will send me, whom, if I have not paid me every morning my forty brace of legs and caps — no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why so, I me fairly accoutred, as becomes a shepherd's servant — but swig for see my master. Here must I quite disrobe myself of all my former manners, garb, behaviour, and put the plod o'th country on. —

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: How now? He whistles and dances:
What jolly whistler have we got here trow?
He, hi, a dancer too? Ay, ay, by'r lady
For ought I know, this is the man I spoke of,
or else if not, here's one could wish he were.
A sturdy knave, a lusty proper knave.
I like him well, he has a back for burdens.
You sirrah, you;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What say you, you?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I say whom do you seek here you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I seek a shepherd you.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I am a shepherd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But I seek a shepherd, whose name is Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I am the man you knave, you come from Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: To serve me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: In good time, how now saucy Jack? how now proud, prodigal knave? where are your twenty legs unto your master? Go to, go to, to work, begin, well said. Anteros makes legs. 1.2.3.4 5 6. So, so, enough, I do forgive the rest. Turn you about, umh, umh, a good squat fellow, a well quartered man, by'r lady, and if he had but moans would make a pretty husband for my daughter Merda.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Has he a daughter? and are there women here? Uh uh uh — oh I am fallen from heaven into a coal-pit!

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Why Merda, I say, my daughter Merda I say, the foolish girl's afraid I know, go to, go to, I will forgive her. Merda I say. But you sir squire o'th' o'th'dog, what is your name? High, which way look you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My name is Jeoffry.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ay, ay, how now? how Jeoffry? A hard name by'r lady. why when?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O I could creep into a catskin purse,
Endure the scent of a court-fardingall
For a concealment now.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Good-honey-sweet-sugarcandy father, forgive me but this time, and if ever I do so any more, I'll never be seen neither bide, or hair again.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ho, ho, oho, ho a great Lob, stand up.
I do forgive you, but on this condition, that for your penance you shall wear this rod, stuck at your back till night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: With all my heart good father stick it on.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: So: how dost thou like my man Chuckin? go to, look on him well.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p:
Does he come a-wooing father? if he does, I'll
run away, and make him believe I'm coy. —[she offers to run into the house. He pulls her back with his hook.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Whither now you great baggage? You'll come again? But stay am not I an old fool? an old dotardly fool, that have not enquired what my man can do yet? Jeoffry. —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is his name Jeoffry? Father, good father do, pray you father let him dwell with us, you know you promised me, that you would hire a man, and buy him a cloak, that he might go before me as they do before gentlefolks daughters, when my new gown was made, I that you did, so marry did you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What have we now to do?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Peace and catch a mouse.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: There's claglocks●now ith' house to make him a cloak sweet — honey — sugar — comfit father let him.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: No more. Jeoffry, how now you slouch? how do you stand? Come hither, go to, go to, did you ever wear a cloak in your life? answer me roundly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No not I, I can't tell how.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ah beggars brat! how now? but I must have you learn, that you may man your young mistress there sometimes. Come on let me see how finely you can do the feat, walk before her, follow him daughter. [he walks, Merda stays behind, tying her shoe.]

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: Here's a sweet office!

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You great lobcock you. [he beats him.]
I'll teach you to look behind you, to see whether your charge follows, or no, what? would you be gadding without your charge?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ay, am I arrived at this? — whoffer did you strike one?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Do you prate too? look you here, mark but me, I have seen the day, when I could have stinged it before my sweet heart. — short and thick citizen like, you mankin, what? two acres breadth at a stride? Ay, I by'r lady; I'll cut you short in smock-timber, for this minion; is your smock so wide, with a murrain to you? short and thick citizen like: how now?

div.head: Act. 4. Sce. 9.
div.stage: Stipes. Anteros. Merda. 2 rustical servants. two maids. Fidlers.

sp.speaker: 1. Rustic
sp.p: High, strike up brave boys, high, for our town.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
High, for your town say you? you are a company of lazy,
lubberly knaves, there's the short and the long on't, ho, ho, boys, ho, ho boys? what drabs too? girls too? doxies too? ye are a company of slowbackly queans, there's sauce for your eels.

sp.speaker: 2. Rustic
sp.p: Come Kate, crowd on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, o, the whole torrent of all woman kind is broke in upon me, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Cuds, cuds, these are Mr. livelyes men and maids, that are come to dance upon the green. Pray you father let me dance with them.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You dance with them? you are a great princockly puplady; there's mustard for your beef too, since you will needs have it; 'sounds I have been a wit in my days, there's some relics left yet, go to, go to.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: O Stipes! I pray you let your daughter dance with us a little.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Dance with you? pray you upsolve me this question, what holy day is this? Latter Lammas? or st. Ginny's even?

sp.speaker: Rustic 1.
sp.p: Come on brave shepherd, our master has given us leave to trip it for an hour, or two, i'faith we have had a wedding at our house today.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: A wedding? A wedding? what wedding? upsolve me that question.

sp.speaker: 1. Rustic
sp.p: Between a gentleman and a gentlewoman, but what care we what they be.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: Come on old Grummelseedes, what must we stand thrumming of caps all day, waiting on your grave ignorance? by the faith of my body, either let your daughter dance with us, or I'll make your old bones rattle in your skin, I'll lead you a coranto i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: An Amazon, by heavens an Amazon, a Penthiseleia.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ay, I by'r lady? are you advised of that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Pray you forsooth, good-hony-sweete-plumpudding father, we'll have but one spir't i'faith la; Sellenger's round in sippits, or put on thy smock on Monday.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: But what flap-mouthed fellow's that behind the tree there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now comes my cue.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Who he? another gates fellow than you take him for, go to, go to, it is my man I tell you.

sp.speaker: 2. Rustic
sp.p: But can be dance?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O in print, he trips it like a fairy.

sp.speaker: Jeffrey.
sp.p: High, high, how now? what? tricks? how now?

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: How now young man? what so modest? come on, take me by th' hand.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Take me Jeoffry. I'll dance with our Jeoffry, or else I won't dance at all, no I won't, law you now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I can't dance.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
He's a lying knave, I saw him myself; to him, to
to him, frolic it nimbly whilst I come back; because 'tis his first day he shall have leave, my daughter too, for half an hour, no more. Go to, go to. Exit Stipes.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 10.
div.stage: Anteros, Merda, two rustical servants, 2. Ancilla, fiddlers.

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.p: But strike it out, we burn daylight.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Ah the lord! but where's our Jeoffrey?

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Cuds me! I doubt the great clown's run away.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Who! he's got up into the tree there.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: Where? where? o cuds wowkers and swowkers, I have him by the leg: Robin, help here robin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a murrain ails you? can't you let one alone?

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.p: Come, come, you must needs dance, we want one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Can't dance.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.l: Can't you dance, my little shamefaced one?
Can you kiss a pretty wench in a corner?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let one alone, I can't I tell you, I won't dance.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: I but you shall sirrah, in spite of your teeth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pish, 'Won't dance.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Come Merda, you must entreat him, he'll dance with you I know.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prithee now Jeoffrey do, prithee now good Jeoffrey do, would I might never stir law, if I don't make you a bisning posset, with a great lump of honey in't, when my father and mother be gone to bed, if you will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pish I can't dance.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: Come let the great fool alone, we'll dance ourselves.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prithee now Jeoffrey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What shall I say? you'll laugh at one.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Would I was whipped if I do.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Be sworn I won't.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Nor I on my maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on then, since there is no remedy.They dance

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.p: He, now every one kiss his marrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I never was miserable till nowMerda wipes her mouth, and expects

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Jeoffrey, Jeoffrey.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Why don't you kiss your marrow?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I won't, I can't kiss.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: No can't? we'll try that: Robin, hold his tother arm fast: so, so, now Merda, now, well said, again, again; why so then. They all laugh.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They live in paradise that thrash.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Tihy.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Tihy, Robin, come hither.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Those happy Paracelsians are in heaven,
That trade by night i'th minerals of the city.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: What do you mean to fight Merda?

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Ay — I forgotten the rod. They laugh.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Fie, why do you blush so Merda? She throws it away.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: I don't blush, you are a liar.

sp.speaker: 1 Russ.
sp.p: Fie upon you Merda, a great maiden, and blush.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Awe, but you lie though, I did not blush, I won't dance no more with you.

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.p: Oh by any means do not forsake us yet, one dance more; who was it that said she blushed? she did not blush, I know she scorns to blush; come take your Jeoffrey by the hand again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'm weary, I can't dance no more.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: Weary? faith I'd squiffe it; weary? about with it I say. They dance again.

div.head: Act. 4. Sce. 11.
div.stage: Stipes, with two dead lambs upon his hook, and caeteri.

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: O lazy varlets! is this a time to dance? you idle persons; what will you leave I say? look here I pray; does this same spectacle agree with turning on the toe, or capering? go to, go to, fie, fie, ah my sweet lambs, I dare be sworn for you, ye think nobody hurt at this instant. Come hither you my nimble skipper, upsolve me this question, what's your 'Pinion must be done with these?

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.p: Pish let's away, strike up, Stipes adieu.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Farewell Merda.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: And you my ninny pease-straw-wisp that cannot kiss.

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.p: Stipes farewell, heigh. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Stipes farewell? but Stipes cannot farewell, if his affairs go thus quite arsy-varsy ; you whoreson crab-faced lizard, you left-legged rogue, what is there nothing else belongs unto this gear, think you, but only to stare on them with your two saucers of mustard? s'duds, either take them up quickly, and to work about them, or I'll —Stipes strikes him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the second time; this once I'll suffer:
but by yond palace of the gods I swear,
Let him but once more touch me with the top
Of his least finger, and I'll ram his trunk
Into the centre: I have said it.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you muttering? you'll in with them, and dispatch them; go you home too, my daughter Merda.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Umh, umh, umh, you might have let one dance a little longer, so you might, so you might; I am not yet hot in my gears. Exeunt Ant. Merda.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you mumbling too? what my whole family turned rebels? s'duds — I promise you, I promise you, 'tis not my best course I see to beat my man thus often; a surly knave by'r lady, a surly knave, a strong knave too, I do not like his looks, he has a vinegar countenance: but peace and catch a mouse, cry I.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: But see, I will inquire; honest man, a word.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Honest man in your face, whosoever owes you; 'sduds, have I nothing to do, but to prittle, prattle, with every one I meet, think you? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What an unheard of rudeness have we here?
Are these the manners of the country? well.
This is the place, as I am told, wherein
That Lucius lives, who not long since prevailed
With his fair flattering speeches, for to have
My son Endymion to be his page.
But o ye awful powers!
I had no father in me should I suffer
Mine only son to lead a servile life
With one that is mine enemy, nay more,
The ruin and subversion of my family.
O daughter Isabella!
Whilst thy false lover melts within the arms
Of his new purchased mistress, thou (Poor girl)
Embracest scorn and poverty, or else
(Which I do rather wish were true) could death.
But I do hear,
Since my arrival, of some country people,
That they have seen, some fortnight since or more,
a pretty boy, lingering about this village
Much about her stature, and complexion,
Which did inquire for a gentleman
That was without a page; this may be she,
Who for the love of Lucius, has put on
Some strange disguise. Whom cannot love transform?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Whilst the poor fly does sport herself too long
About the amorous flame, she burns her wings.
Her counterfeiting of a love, is now
Turned into earnest. Endymion's now the man
She swears she loves; as for the other two
She has forgotten their very names already.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Does not this woman name my son?
Let me see, is not this Endymion? it is he,Enter Pand. Endymion.
And with him a fair gentlewoman. Ha?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: But tell me dearest, did thy master Lucius.
Once love thy sister Isabella so,
Whom now he has forsaken?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Behold
That treachery repaid him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: See, they kiss.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But what old gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll show myself.
All health to this fair loving couple.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why dost thou fly me?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis my father, — father
God save you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Dearest son, my best of blessings.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How have you done sir, since I saw you last?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: As well as one can do that has departed
With's only daughter.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why, is my sister dead?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: I know not that. But I am sure her credit,
The candour of her name is perished.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good sir, as how? Instruct me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah Endymion,
Since that most treacherous Lucius left the city
I have not seen her, only I hear of her,
But little to my comfort. — but no more,
I have forgotten her, and her folly both.
Prepare thyself (My son) immediately,
To leave this place and service; for thy fortunes
(How ere they were before, slender and poor)
must not now see thee hold a trencher for
A better man than Lucius. Thy old uncle
As he lived well, in a seasonable age
Is gone into the grave, and by his will
Hath given to thee eight thousand pound, and three
Unto thy sister, (Though unworthy) what
Else he was worth in lands and goods, is mine.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pandora, kiss me girl, kiss me I say,
I have deserved it, 'twas my invention,
My plot this (Girl) thou'rt happy wench, thou'rt happy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is this your father sweet?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It is fair mistress.
Sir, I congratulate our fortunes with you;
But if you do desire to have my joys
Full and o'erflow their banks, grant me your leave
To marry this fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Alas,
This is not in my power Endymion:
But if thou canst procure her friend's consent —

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir fear not that, I will entreat my father.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: As for a portion, 'tis not thought upon
My son, if you be pleased.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Sir, I am pleased,
She is to me most dear.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Placenta, run,
See if my father be within, — I knowEx. Pla.
(Most worthy sir) that I shall win him to it.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: But canst thou tell no news of Isabella,
Sweet son?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, none at all sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah poor heart!
But 'tis no matter, I'll forget her quite. Redit in scenam Plac.
Where is thy Mr. Lucius?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your father's walked abroad with mist. Ursely
Your sister, but whither, there's none can tell me.
As yet the plot concerning ConstantinaTo herself.
Is not descried.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Most reverend sir, wilt please you
To walk into the pastures, peradventure
There we shall meet my father.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But I had rather
That I could compass that same villain Lucius,
That he might hear what he deserves. Liuely runs in, Nean. following with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Villain.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ah me! Neander with his naked sword!
I'll run in here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let's away good father,Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: O that thou hadst
As many lives as hairs, that I might be
An age in killing thee, that I might score up
Each passing minute with a life: — but speak,
How durst thou thus abuse me?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: I did not know
She was a woman.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: No, didst thou not know it?
But thou shalt know thyself to be a man,
One that can die.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: — O — oh —

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: How poor is this revenge? hast thou any children,
Or kinsfolks (Speak) that I may kill them too?
Ha? wilt thou not answer? how durst thou offer this?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Because I loved your friend Lucius
Better than you.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Better then I? that word
Does merit death though thou hadst been preserved
White from thy cradle to this hour. —
Dost thou love Lucius? ha?

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Live; no, no thou must not;
Thou mightst have killed my father, broke the urn
Wherein my mother's ashes sleep, far cheaper.
But for his sake, thus much I'll grant thee, choose
The manner of thy death — shall I take off thy head?
Or hadst thou rather die upon the point?
Think quickly, nay be instant.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Worthy sir:
Let me entreat some little space to pause
I have not yet determined.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Well thou hast it. But see that it be speedy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Most perfidious. Contemner of all goodness. —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Excellent.
Nay forward, on, we know you have a tongue.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ha? is this Lucius?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Where is my Isabella,
Whom thou hast loaden with disgrace? restore me
Her honour (Villain) her good name.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I must
Defer my just revenge I see a little.
He must not know that I am angry, not
how I am gulled.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou base unworthy man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Would you could raise your voice a little sir,
You are not heard.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou stain of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Thou owest thy life unto my Lucius.
I am not now at leisure for to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Nor I for to be killed for a trick I know. Ex. liuely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are you drawn dry so quickly, Mr. Lickthumb?
Have you no more good names in pickle for me?
Nay come i'faith, let's have another bout.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: But is he gone? he must not so escape me. Ex. Nean.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Where is my daughter? where is my daughter, rascal?
Ah Isabella.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So: but sir resolve me,
Have ye no empirics? no physicians
I'th city, that you thus do send your mad men
Into the country to be cured? but sir
I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: But I will not so leave you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will not?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, I'll be a torment to thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will? but yet take heed that your ill language
Procures not me to turn physician.
This sword of mine opens a vein but harshly,
Do you hear.

lg.l: Have you a desire to see
The glorious heaven's epitome?
Or an abstract of the spring?
Adonis garden? or a thing
Fuller of wonder, nature's shop displayed,
Hung with the choicest pieces she has made?
Here behold it open laid.
Or else would you bless your eyes
With a type of paradise?
Or behold how poets feign
Jove to sit amid his train?
Or see (What made Actaeon rue)
Diana amongst her virgin crew?
Lift up your eyes and view.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 1.
div.l: Why so then, now we are all alone. We? you great near,
What have you pigs in your belly? by'r lady, if I wist
I had, I would not unkennel this secret yet, well if there
Were hog's in my belly too, I see that it will out;
This mouth of mine was not cut out for secrets —
Oh wicked servant! lewd daughter!
O Merda, Merda, thou hast lost thyself
div.p: For ever, thou hast defiled my house, my good name, my family. As I even now came from my sheep, I found my daughter, at her nooning forsooth, fast asleep upon her bed, and there was she (As she uses often) campering to herself alone in her sleep, 'scoursing to herself, but what was herdiscourse think you? Not about her housewifery; not how many hens were with egg, but fie upon you Jeoffry are you not ashamed? O! ah! fie upon you Jeoffry are you not ashamed to touch one by the skin? I'll tell my father (Never move) if you will not be quiet. Ay, I by'r lady, worse than this, worse stuff than this, what shall I say? without all doubt this left legged-rascall has dubbed me grandfather without matrimony. But peace and catch a mouse cry I, some wiser than some, old birds will not be catched with shaffe. I have a trick in store if it will take, to be revenged sufficiently — no more. Jeoffry, why Jeoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What gaping knave is that?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: How now Jeoffry? know you not me Jeoffry? know you not me? But let that pass though — I'll be with you anon i'faith for all this gear. Come hither left-legs, come hither. Peace and catch a mouse cry I. Did you ever when you were at your old masters, learn to set a trap, Jeoffry?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes a mouse trap.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
O sirrah, sirrah; but we must have to do with other gates kind of cattle, I mean a fox trap left-legs, come hither, come hither, look you here, and learn, for this same night must
I send you into the pastures to invite my fine Reynold tomorrow to breakfast, go too, go too, he is something too familiar with my lambs, mark you that left-legs? A little nigher I pray you. Help me to twist this cord — well said, be a faithful servant Jeoffry. You know I have a daughter Jeoffry. Peace and catch a mouse Jeoffry. You great dunder nose — 'zounds — you'll lay both hands to work — a bots on you; you hang on my back to see you. Your tother hand in, and draw behind thus, thus look you here. [he gets his hands into the cords, and on a sudden ties him too a tree.]ha, ha, he, foh. How rank he smells? but 'tis no matter, I begin to grow old, and 'tis good (They say) against the palsy. Ha, ha, he, he, ho. You villain, he loves
Mutton well, that dips his bread in'th wool.
No less than your master's daughter left-legs?
Come on in troth, upsolve me this question is she not tender? is she not delicate? A pretty morsel? does she not relish well?
