A pretty morsel? but I'll teach you sirrah to play the mason, and lay your chips o'th rock where you're desired left-legs, where you're desired. But I am something feeble through my age,
And cannot longer hold out discourse with you,
Without my staff, without my supporter, sir,
I pray you do not stir till my return,
But let me find you here, I have some business,
Go to, go to, I have some business with you. Exit Stipes.

div.head: Act. 5. Sce. 3.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay 'tis no matter I deserve it all,
Troth I do hope that he will baste me soundly.
Beshrew his fingers if he does not, soundly.
I must be in my tricks, forsooth, my tricks:
Have my devices, and my turns, my changes. Enter Loveall.
But torment of all torments! here comes Love-all.
Why this is worse than five and twenty beatings;
Oh that some greedy undertaker of lives
Would give me but a double stiver now
For mine, that I might cozen him. As sure
As death, or justice hooks devouring paws,
I shall be jeered to death, immediately.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: It is a strange dark melancholy this
That thus torments my sister, I have been
An hour with her, and in all that time
Cannot persuade her troubled soul to form
The least air she breathes, into articulate language.
But stay what have we here?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now it begins.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: A man tied to a tree?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would your tongue
Was tied as fast; then there was hope I might
Escape with life.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What are you fellow, speak?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may go look, go meddle with your own.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: So angry pray thee? how came thy hands in mortgage?
Shall I redeem them?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Redeem your own lands I pray you,
Let me alone or else I'll spurn you — yet
He knows me not.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sure I have seen that face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, o, oh —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Is 't he or not, ha? Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more.
Death not a word.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But heaven and earth man! how
Comes this to pass? What has begotten this change?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wilt thou untie me? I will tell thee all.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But pray thee Anteros. —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But pray thee Jack
Thou wilt undo me quite by thy delays,
Wilt thou undo me?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis not a friendly part.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pox of that jest, as common as a woman,
Or her synonomy; wilt thou untie me? He unties him.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou art my patron Love-all, so.
But stay a while, I must desire your aid
A little further.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What has he now in hand?

div.stage: [he pulls off his shepherd's robes which were above his own, plucks garters, pumps, roses, a band out of his pocket.]

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you become a peaceable man?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: How now?
A snake, a snake; he's young again, ha, ha, he.
What? Pinks and roses too? Why so, he plucks
June out of is pocket.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you be quiet yet?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And garters too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That slipper ▪ tongue of yours
I doubt will spoil all.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What? and a band? so, so;
The veil of tempe's not so fresh, the picture,
the very picture of the spring, when th' earth
Lays by her freeze-coat, and turns forester.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus far it prospers, once more your help sweet Jack,
Nay come, and take me that same rope again,
And bind me as I was before, directly
In the same garb you found me — do not stand
Gazing, but do 't.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Thou art not mad I hope?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If I be mad, I will not trouble you
For counsel, nor for physic; nay wilt thou come?
But hold a little, I must first borrow of you
Your hat, and sword. [he lends him his hat and sword.]

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Which way this plot will look
I know not — there — come let me see your hand's
Since you will needs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why now thou'rt right, thou'rt right,

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What will you have me do besides? come on,
Your legs too if you will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more, st. hark.
The shepherds door. Trouble us not good Love-all.
Only stand close and hear.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What should this mean?

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 4.
div.stage: Stipes with a cudgel in his hand. Anteros. Loveall.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Fie Jeoffry, are you not ashamed, to touch one by the skin? My daughter denies all this most stiffly but I will ferret-claw my lobcock i'faith. So, now I am armed. Go to, go to, come you knave, where are you?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ha? ha? ha? How now by'r lady? How now? Ay, I by'r lady? what's this? What's this? gaudy? gaudy? Fine clothes? fine clothes? Ha? has nobody stole my eyes? let me be sure of that in the first place. Am I Stipes or not? ha? ha? ha? Is this our Jeoffry or not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Stipes, Stipes I say.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: This is another voice another face
Without all question this is fairy ground;
My man is changed.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St. Stip. hi, hi, hi. A sword too? A sword too? A whiniard too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip
sp.p: Well I will venture to speak whate'er come on 't, but stay, I'll first say o'er the charm my mother learned me.
sp.l: Be'st thou devil gentle, or beest thou devil cursed,
in the name of saint Swithin do thy worst.
sp.p: There's sauce for your eels whate'er you are. Now see if I cannot shape you an answer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come nearer to me.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you advised of that? older and wiser, soft fire makes sweet malt, no haste to hang true men; come nearer quoth you? I am near enough already for the good you'll do me I doubt, come nearer say you? No good m. devil I am very well I thank you, go to, come nearer when you have a sword, a twybill?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My hands are bound man.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: What will become of this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St '. Stip. if your feet were bound too, I'll not trust you as long as you have a sword by your side, a whiniard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do but hear me. Had not you a man today called Jeoffry?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Yes marry had I; what say you to that now? Nay I'll keep myself out of your clutches I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But what's become of that same Jeoffry?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Become? become? 'Suppose I spurred you an answer, and said I know not, what can you make of that now? make me a horse-nail of that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you desire to know?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Yes marry do I. Crack me that nut now if you be a gentleman devil. —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am that Jeoffry, but no servant now
Of yours, but mine own man: and am become
Since your departure, noble, rich, valiant,
Am formed a new out of the mint, — behold me.
And this great miracle Obron the fairy King
Has wrought upon me.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Oberum? Oberum? you tell me strange things.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But shall I tell thee stranger things than these?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: 'Suppose you did.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And such as shall be for thy benefit? —

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Would you would else. Nay stare on with your goggles till barley comes to six pence a bushel. You know your wages, some wiser than some, cry I: I'll keep far enough off you: I'll tell you but so. Go to, go to, I am a crafty colt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You know I was your servant today.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Well put the case.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Poor, ill apparelled.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Put the case the second time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But now you see how strangely altered.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Well put the case again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What will you say now to the man that shall
Pet you into the same condition?
Recover you from rags and russet, and
die you in scarlet: lick that rude lump your body
Into the shape, and garb o'th court? or (Once)
Make you a gentleman as I am now?
Would you not thank him Stipes? ha? would you not thank him?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Thank him Mr. Jeoffry? Ay, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Set him at liberty then that will perform it. Quickly unloose me? [he unties him.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ay, I by'r lady? will you so Mr. Jeoffry? will you so? go to, go to, a gentleman? said you me so? I con you thank Mr. Jeoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, now will I unfold the mystery.
But first you here shall promise me that you
Will take no prentices to learn your trade,
When I have taught you the art; you will impoverish
The herald's office, and forestall his market.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: No truly Mr. Jeoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am satisfied;
Seest thou that tree? 'twas made for thy advancement.
Give me thy hands that I may tie them quickly.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you advised of that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What do you mean?
You'll be prevented by another — death!
Yonder comes one will be before you — quickly
There's such a virtue (Man) in this same tree,
That whosoe'er is bound unto it, shall
Be turned immediately to a gentleman.
Nay come.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But is this true?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Believe your eyes.
Heart of my father, man! you'll be prevented.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: A gentleman? said you me so? go to, go to,[he ties Stipes to the tree.]good master Jeoffry quickly — so but stay. When I'm a gentleman may I not use, my old trade of shepherd still? I would not leave it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, and enclose; 'tis all in fashion.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ay, ay, by'r lady? that's well, but stay again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay you are like to stay now, I have you fast enough

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: 'Sduds, if thou beest a good conjurer make me a knight to. I have a pestilent itch after a knighthood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You must take gentleman first ith' way.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Let me skip gentleman good Mr. Jeoffry, 'Duds
I know knights in this country that never were
Gentlemen — but upsolve me this question? can you make
My daughter Merda a gentleman too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A gentlewoman
Stipes I can.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Ay, ay, so I meant it — Merda, Merda,
A bots on you, Merda, are you dreaming again?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O for some nimble pated fellow now
To make an Ob'ron of.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I'll furnish thee.
There is a notable witty bedlam begging
At our back gate just now. I'll fetch him to thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If thou dost love me, do. —Exit Loveall.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Why Merda, you'll come when your noun father calls?

div.head: Act. 5. Sce. 5.
div.stage: Merda. Stipes. Anteros. Loveall. A bedlam.

sp.speaker: Merda.
sp.p: What do you say father forsooth?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: That is a good girl. Nay she is towardly enough, she'll quickly learn. Why do you stare so on Mr. Jeoffry?

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: What man is this father?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Come you're a fool, let that man alone. We shall be gentlefolks ourselves my chucken, give him your hands to tie I say, be obedient.
sp.l: Thou presently shalt see thine own sweet father,
As fine as he, and thou my little sweet-lips
Shalt be a gentlewoman too, go to, good Jeoffry tie her hands.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How Jeoffry?

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: Good Mr. Jeoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's another thing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Father forsooth shall I have as fine clothes on as mistress Ursly forsooth?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O! she's half turned already: forsooth and a curtsy at every word; Mrs. Ursely? thou shalt put Mrs. Ursly into a pint pot.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: O the lord! pray you forsooth sir whosoe'er you are do me quickly forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But here is not rope enough.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Take off your garter quickly you Maukin you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Here forsooth. And father, must I take place of my mother when I'm a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Marry shalt thou goldy locks, and be a lady, and contemn her.
Call her the good old country woman too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stipes, but one word more and then I'll leave you
Unto your new creation — have you nothing
Within your house to cover you? the crows
Perhaps may be too impudent and saucy
With you, and now you can not help yourself you know.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Ay, I by'r lady? 'twas well thought upon,
Good Mr. Jeoffry step into my house,He goes out and returns presently with a long grey cloak.
You there shall find my cloak, use that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis of a swooping cut, but new be sure
You do not speak a word what noise soe'er
You chance to hear, perhaps the fairy King
Will take some pause, study a while, consult
With his Queen Mab about you how to polish
And frame you of a purer shape then ordinary.
Do you mark that? St, not a word good Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip
sp.p: Ah sweet Mr. Jeoffry. [enter Loveall with a bedlam.]

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace and catch a mouse cry I.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come on brave Tom, come on brave Tom, remember your instructions Tom.

sp.speaker: Bedl.
sp.p: Let brave Tom alone. Let brave Tom alone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A most authentic rogue, how he does stretch it? paratragoediate?

sp.speaker: Bedlam sings.
sp.l: Newly from a poached trade, and
A broil a viper, King of fairy land
I Ob'ron do arise, to see
What mortal fortune here hath tied unto my sacred tree.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O Mr. Jeoffry, is that Ob'rum? Pray you let me see him. [an't lifts up the cloak and Stipes sees him.]is this Obrum? 'sduds, he is but poorly apparelled himself methinks .

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St. Stip. peace and catch a mouse cry I, but once more good Mr. Jeoffry. Let me have butAnt lifts up the cloak again.one sight more of him. Mr. Jeoffry does he use to give away his clothes when he makes gentlefolks? 'sduds I doubt he has none left for me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Peace and catch a mouse cry I.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good father let me see Obrum too : ah, he has a horn like a Tom of bedlam.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Peace, I would not for the best cow in my yard that he should hear thee.

sp.speaker: Bedlam sings.
sp.l: Be'st thou ruder than was e'er
The half excrement of a bear,
Or rougher than the Northern wind
Camest thou of a satyr's kind.
Be whatsoever thou canst be
So thou shalt remain for me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Did you hear that Stipes?

sp.speaker: Stip:
sp.p:
Ay, good master
Jeoffry, stand farther you great baggage and make room for your rathers 'Proaching greatness.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But see my father,

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Pray thee convey away the bedlam any whether, carry him into your house again and shoot him out at the back door.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Anteros, I'll leave you to your business. I'll in and fetch another hat. Come brave tom. 'Bed, let brave Tom alone. [ex. Lou. and bedlam.]

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The justice too, 'tis so. Now am I hunted for about a wedding.

div.head: Act. 5. Sce. 6.
div.stage: Justice hook, Terpander, Anteros Mrs. Ursly.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: Terpander, you have heard how much this match
May both concern you and your son, your fortunes:
The greater part of your inheritance
You know is mortgaged to me, nay(I'll tell you)
If I would use that rigour of the law
'Tis forfeited and past recovery;
Think therefore quickly, if you would be free
From all those cares and troubles which afflict
Such as do live in debt, compel your son
To marry this my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am a witch,
A witch, a witch a rank, stark stinking witch.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: It is an ample dowry I confess,
And little 'tis agreeing to my nature
To buy a husband at so dear a rate,
But I have something that sounds father in me;
And must not lose a daughter, if there be
A remedy in nature. True it is,
That (By what angry deity I know not)
She has so fixed her love upon your son,
That I do think naught but a quick fruition
Can rescue her from a death.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Good justice hook,
I do confess your offer's fair, and would
Accept it willingly, but that —

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I fear my son will not agree unto 't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir had you taken an oath upon the same
I would have born your sin, had you been perjured.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You know he hates all women.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: Very good.
Is he not yours, and under your command?
We fathers make our children refractory,
By being too indulgent over them;
besides, I am persuaded that his virtues
Will not permit him for to contradict
Th' authority of a father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O ye gods!
Can ye permit this villain to profane
The sacred name of virtue thus, who himself
Is nothing else but a mere heap of vices?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I ever yet found him obedient,
Nor do I doubt to win him now: however ,
I am resolved if he in this shall cross me,
I'll disinherit him immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I? is it come to that already? well
Prepare thyself now Anteros for th' encounter.

sp.speaker: Hooke,
sp.l: But see your son. 'tis your best course at first
To accost him gently.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How now my son? how fare you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am not well sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How not well? your colour
Does not proclaim you very sick, but say.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's something in my eyes that troubles me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A mote, a woman.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: After the old fashion still?
Come on my son, I have been seeking of you,
And peradventure you may guess the cause.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would I could not.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: Hold up your head my daughter
And summon your best looks into your face.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As I did walk even now into my pasture,
I did begin to think.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That I was old,
That must be next.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: That now I'm struck in years.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good, struck in years;
And could he not as frugally have dispatched it
In that one word of old?

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: And —

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: That it will be a comfortable sight
To see you married before I die.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: That it will be a comfortable sight
To see you married before my death.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: I told you so, it is the common road
Which they all use when they would pin a wife
Upon the son. I wonder all this while
The staff of's age, prop of his family
Did not come in.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: Whilst I was thinking thus,
Old justice hook, a gentleman of rank,
And of a family not to be despised,
Came to me with his daughter, and desired
our friendship and affinity; and to be brief,
We have concluded 'twixt ye two a marriage,
Which must be present; as for the portion,
Has promised in the wedding fire to sacrifice
The bonds wherein our lands stand forfeited.
A thing beyond my hopes, or your deserts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pox upon that thumb under the girdle,
There is mischief ever toward's: I never knew
One of that garb that proved an honest man.
'Tis the grave cheating posture of the city.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What's that you mutter to yourself? come speak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am contented sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Well said my son.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But upon this condition, that it shall
Be lawful too for me to sacrifice
Unto the aforesaid fire a certain trifle
Of mine.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: An●.
sp.l: My wife, and your fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Out on you traitor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, by yea and nay
It cannot be afforded cheaper.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Wretch
And profane person.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Sayest thou so thou villain?
Hast thou no more regard into thy father,
Nor to his shipwrackt fortune, that thou thus ▪
Dost study his undoing plot his 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But father, if I marry her today,
When must the wooing be? tomorrow sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Thou shalt not need to woo her Anteros,
She is thine own already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is she so?
Would you was hanged sir for the nowes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Pish, dome,
I will not spend an article of air
Upon him more — good Mr. hook let's go,
The following hour shall see him no son of mine.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O, mildly sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is determined
By all the stars, they have consulted, plotted
To make me miserable.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come Terpander,
You are too harsh with him, I know your son
Does more esteem of virtue and religion —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good master sacrilege, a word in private:
(A little farther, yet a little farther)
How came you by that strange exotic word
You used but now? had you're on interest?
Or was it lent you gratis of a friend?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: What word good Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Religion,
For I am sure yet thou never hadst,
Nor ever wilt have any of thine own.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O profane person!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: This once I speak it.
Wilt have his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What shall I answer him?
I shall be disinherited that's certain.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: He melts, Mr. hook, he melts, I feel him coming.
He is our own.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But why so suddenly?
Good sir, at least give me some time to think.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Never hope it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But why sir today?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Because it pleaseth him it most concerns.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do but defer it till tomorrow sir,
(Could I obtain but this request, I was happy,Aside.
I'd keep tomorrow in another world)

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Until tomorrow? not for an hour: I know
Your disposition son too well for that.
I have you now, but where you'll be next day,
He is wiser than your father that does know.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But father, I beseech you hear.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: But son
I will not hear, I tell you. Master hook,
You here do give your daughter?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Willingly.
Anteros, receive thy loving wife.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How now?
You will not urge me? — go too, do not do it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O that mine arms are now at liberty!
O Stipes, happiest man alive, thou hast
No hands to make a contract, — is there never
A mousehole hereabouts to creep into?
But stay a while, my paper portion.
The writings.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Take them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You're an honest man.
sp.stage: [he gives them him, and Ant. tears them in pieces.]
sp.l: 'Tis right.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Now take your wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wish you a barber sir.
Is that fair edifice yours?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: It is my son.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gooder and gooder still; my son? then take
My counsel sir, go to your house and purge,
You will be mad else presently; prevent
The current of the humour, for I see
(With that poor little reading which I have
I'th volume of man) by your distempered looks,
That some strange deep, and conquering melancholy
ere long will seize you: why do you follow me
Thus with your braided ware? nay never frown,
Good Mr. justice, let's have no warrants made,
Nor mittimuses with your distorted looks;
We have a forehead too, and can look grim,
And make as ugly and prodigious faces,
As the most ignorant justice of you all.
But shall I tell you (Sweet Mr. velvet-hose)
What I will do, because you were so kind,
For to deliver in the bonds for nothing?
Nay sir, I must transplant these thumbs, before
I can resolve you: so. — thou'rt a damned rascal,
And I will cut that throat of thine (Do you mark?)
And when I've done, will fillip that morsel, woman,
On an embassage to my hawks, no more;
By heavens I'll do 't.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O traitor, miscreant,
Daughter take heed; Terpander, oh Terpander,
He threatens me to cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, you must pardon him, the man is mad.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: He swears he will make hawksmeat of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: On my virginity sir, he does me wrong;
I did not charge a syllable upon him,
But fell as coolly from me as a dew.
Upon a drooping field; each word I vented
Was steeped in an honeycomb. I did but bid him
In a plain, civil dialect to provide
Another husband for his daughter: for
I doubted that I should not be at leisure
This brace or two of years to marry her.
And I may tell you sir, indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O, o, am undone, cheated and gulled, undone,
Villain I'll bind thee to thy good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would you could sir, I would thank you for't:
But fie m. hook, a head of that silver die,
A beard of such an honourable length,
For to be gulled? and so egregiously?
By a young man with never a hair on's face?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Come son, I do not like these courses, nor
Do they become a gentleman, I'll not have
That contumely dwell on our family,
that we should use such indirect proceedings
For to re-edify our tottering fortunes.
By all the magic in the name of father
I do conjure thee; by this aged head,
And these grey hairs, by thy dead mother's urn,
By all her cares and fears, by what is dearest
Unto thy soul, I charge thee, take his daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Without all question I am the first, the first
That ever piety has made miserable.
Well master hook, you see what may be done,
What angry spirits a man may lay, while he
Does stand secure within the circle of father.
Your daughter I will have; only know this,
There is another thing which belongs to her,
Which I must have too, that's the parsonage;
'Twas ever yet allotted for her portion,
And I expect my right.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: How? woe is me,
I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Before I stretch forth a paw
Towards her, I'll have it.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Father, good father let him,
He will go back from's word else.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Well, he shall have it.
Hold: by the virtue of this writing, it
Is lawful for you (After old Lively's death)
For to present the first fie, fie, fie, fie.
I had this drawn (Alas) for another end.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My law does tell me it will do. Come on,
Since there's no remedy, let's even to't.
Yes hangman, I forgive thee heartily,
'Tis but thy office.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come Terpander, we
Will keep the wedding, at my house, but hear you?
The cost and charges shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Agreed,
Most willingly. Follow me son and daughter.

div.stage: [she fits down, and pulls stones out of her pocket]

sp.speaker: Vrse.
sp.l: Come husband Anteros, will you play at checkstones
With me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow, follow,
I will be there immediately: nay go.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: So, I have made a fine days work of this: —
Well, there's no remedy, it must be so.
But I must take my leave in form: farewell
Ye chimney gods, protectors of our family;
Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: A bott's upon you, that same tongue
Of yours must needs be wagging.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed father
I did not speak a word, no that I did not.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: We must begin again now for your tattling,
Did not the gentleman command us silence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stipes adieu, I am exceeding sorry
I cannot stay to see you a gentleman.
Spruce m. noddle, even adieu to you.
Good m. mongrel, kind sir Hammershin.
Sweet m. William, I am melancholy
To part with you as I am a living soul.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why whether in such haste?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To banishment.
My name is written in the oyster shell;
I am too happy in a wife Jack Love-all,
My fellow citizens do envy me.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: In troth I thank you heartily,
I hope you'll first deliver back again
My sword and hat.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By my best wishes Jack
I thought not of them; pray thee take them to thee.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I will take thee my little cupid-whipper.
You must not go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let me alone good Love-all,
Dost thou not hear how with an even gale
That Southwest wind murmurs amongst the trees?
Within these four and twenty hours I may
Touch on the Belgic shore.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The Belgic shore?
What wilt thou do there man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll trail a pike,
Turn lanceprezado, or bedee, or any thing
To patch up a wretched life.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You'll turn a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I never shall endure to live a husband
The very name of wife will turn my stomach.
I shall have threescore vomits in a day.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What wilt thou say now Anteros if I set thee
As free from this same marriage, as the child
Which ten months since was but an embryo?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I can do it, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou canst nor man, 'tis past recovery.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What wilt thou give me if I do effect it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give thee? I'll sacrifice myself unto thee
My Jupiter, build up a temple for thee
Shall take the heavens from Atlas' shoulders, and
Give him a jubilee for ever — speak.
He shall be at leisure all the rest of's life,
For to catch butterflies — but you do mock me,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But stay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do but effect it Jack.
And I will straight make war upon the Turk,
Give thee his diadem and sceptre — speak.
The Persian shall be the master of thy horse,
The german I will make thy cupbearer.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he. And so I shall have all my drink drunk up,
Thank you for that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay wilt thou speak, or else
Let me be gone. — the Dukes of Italy
Shall be thy footboys.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Here's a brave promiser!
Why this out does the court; but dost thou hear?
How wilt thou do all this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay 'Troth I know not,
But I will do it, and let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Well then be silent. — Placenta the shepherd's wife
Soon as she heard a marriage was in motion
Betwixt my kinswoman and yourself, came running
To me in haste, and cried what do they mean?
It is not fit, nor can it be (Unless
That they will violate the laws of nature)
That Anteros should have this gentlewoman;
I ask the cause, the midwife answereth
Because she is his sister.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How? my sister?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And is it possible that this is true?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay will you hear with patience?
Or else —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As silent as a midnight minute,
Or else a counsellor without a fee,
I'll stand and hear, and suck it in, and —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Yet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I've done.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Then hear; it seems that Dorothea
My uncle's wife, some seventeen years ago
Supposing she had been with child, provided
Such necessaries for her, as a woman
That is in her estate might stand in need of;
'Twas famed about the country: but at last
she found herself deluded by a tympany,
But fearing lest she should prove the table talk o'th country,
Takes counsel with Placenta for to feign
A birth, and to that end employeth her
(Being a midwife) to procure for money,
The child of some poor woman new delivered.
At the same time it fortuned Anteros
That your mother cried for innos help,
Which she obtained, and was delivered
Of this your sister, whom when she perceived
To be deformed, and distorted; at length
She was overcome by th' midwife for to part
With her new purchased infant, was agreed,
And the birth straight given out to be abortive,
And which is more, believed, and for to colour
The matter o'er the better, they did bury
An empty coffin. In the mean time your sister
Was secretly conveyed unto my aunt,
Who presently did feign to be in travail,
And was delivered in conceit of her,
Who but a while ago was called your wife.
Was not long after, but the brace of mothers
Did travail both together to the dead,
And left my uncle a supposed daughter.
You have the history.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And with it heaven,
And immortality: oh Loveall, Loveall;
By all the deities I could embrace thee
For this thy happy news, were't thou a woman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: But what's become of all your promises?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O 'tis a taste, a spice of greatness, Jack,
To promise.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And to perform just nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You do not hear me say so. What's the matter?

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena 9.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: But see the wooers are discarded quite
My uncle beats them out of doors.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: You villains —
Out of my house ye brood of caterpillars. —
Son of a hedge and moonshine; go — fie, fie, fie.
O misery beyond — come out you rascal,
And bring your piping nose along with you; —
A fire upon this hollow ruff of yours,
'Tis like your heart — out rogues, and ruffians —
Oh I am undone. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he. Loveall, these men are mine;
I am the patron of the living now,
Dost thou see this?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I heard as much within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will behave myself most scurvily,
Like to some surly crabbed patron now,
That has some 6, or 7 tired horses tied
At's door. How now?

sp.speaker: Zealous
sp.l: Patron.

div.stage: He salutes Anteros winking, he in the mean time cuts away the black box that hung at his girdle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What says my client?
Loveall, I pray thee catechise this box,
There's good stuff in 't I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Zealous
sp.l: Good patron.

sp.speaker: Arthur.
sp.l: Hear me sir, I'll dispatch it in three words,
This is a tedious ass, and readeth naught
But English treatises.

sp.speaker: Zealous
sp.l: Sir, will it please you
To take particular notice? —

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: But patron —

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Patron.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who! now the scent grows hot, 'tis rank,
The game's in view. Haup, — rate them there — no more
You sir, that are the ringleader of this rout. —

sp.speaker: Zealous
sp.l: Kings be profane.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Sdeath! what a pack of rogues
Are got together here? what is your name?

sp.speaker: Zeal.
sp.l: Zealous Knowlittle:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Zealous Knowlittle? good;
Of which university?

sp.speaker: Zeal.
sp.l: Of both the universities.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A very likely thing: good Mr. Knowlittle
Separate yourself a little from the people.

sp.speaker: Zeal.
sp.l: With all my heart, I'll separate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: My name is tempest Allmouth sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How? Tempest Almouth? where are thy brains man?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.l: He has not any.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bear him company.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What have we here? Item, to send forth tickets
To all the brothers that do inhabit
Within this shire, to give them intimation,
That m. mother-tongue stands the first of June.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You that are next him?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Arthur Armstrong sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You there colosse?

sp.speaker: Stutch:
sp.l: My name is Stutchell Legg.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Troth, and thou art well underlaid indeed,
A couple of football players I warrant them.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Item: — a pox upon't, here's bawdry,
I'll rake no deeper in this puddle. — so.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: And what must we call you?

sp.speaker: Gan:
sp.l: Ganymede Filpot ▪

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Thou shouldst be a good fellow by thy name.
Come on; what glorious title I beseech you
Has bounteous nature fixed on you: nay open.

sp.speaker: Hugo.
sp.l: My name is Hugo obligation.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: How? Hugo obligation? Pray thee Loveall
Is not this shorn beard villain the precise Scrivener,
Would fain turn priest?

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: The very same I take it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Meddle not with me

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.l: Nay do not hold me.
A whoreson Inkbottle, and two skins of parchment,He draws his sword.
Dares he hope for my sister, and a living?
You slave, are parsonages in this age so cheap?

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: Pray thee Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Do not entreat me Loveall,
He dies: this hat is not more mortified.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: Pray thee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Hang him, a death's too good
For such a rascal. — sirrah, i'll indenturs
Upon your skin. And here's another villain,
Whose very countenance speaks servingman,
Filpot come hither.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nay but Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Death man! our universities do swarm,
They have more scholars than they know to spend
While they are sweet: and must such rogues as these,
Whose height of knowledge, is to spit and snuffle,
And talk some 3. hours nonsense, shoulder them
Out of their places? what is 't that makes so many
Of our quick wit's turn Jesuits, and forsake
Both their religion, and their country think you?
Sirrah no more than thus, lie and thou diest.
Have not you been a serving man sometimes?

sp.speaker: Gan:
sp.l: Yes truly sir, I'll not deny't, I was
A gentleman's butler once.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: I told you so.
The very chippings hang in's eyebrows still.
His face unto this instant minute shines
With broken beer that was his fees, stand by,
and do not hope so large a benefit
From me as to be killed, live, live, unhappy.
You m. know little know you whose box is this?

sp.speaker: Zeal:
sp.l: Truly 'tis mine, verily.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Away you stinkards,
I will be visited no more today.
Avoid I say. Have I not done it well? Exeunt suitors.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: O no, you want the pawls, and the hums,
And the grave thumb under the girdle too.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: O, that's for old living brokers, I'm a young one.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You must indent then with them, for to keep you
Some hounds or cocks, and get a handsome wife
To entertain you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A wife? A thunderbolt
Is entered me, pray thee no more.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: How now?

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena 10.
div.stage: Justice hook, Terpander, mistress Ursly, Loveall, Anteros, Placenta, Neander, Constantina (As dead,) brought in by two of Lively's servants, three fiddlers, one of them carries all the fiddles, and Neander's sword, the other two lead him in.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: And get you packing too, thou old impostor,
With your distorted puppet here; and you
That make the custards quake where ere you come,
Thou enemy to sweet meats.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Mr. hook
'Twould relish more of wisdom if you did
Bear out this matter coolly. Come my daughter.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: O me! the very boy's will laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Anteros salute your sister, and embrace her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am undone again! what shall I do
Loveall?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What shall you do? why kiss her man.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Sister god save you, — and as much to you
My never-to-be-hereafter father in law.

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: Woe's me! what shall I say? what shall I do?
I have given in the mortgage, and without money.
But what new spectacle is this?

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: What's here?
How? the dead body of a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: Is this Neander?

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.l: Hold the cut throat fiddlers
Whilst we do bring this gentlewoman 'fore the justice.

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.l: A kind and loving husband sure, that has.
Made a fair hand on's wife thus the first day.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: Ha? what is this I see? O traitorous eyes:
Can I believe ye any more? my sister?
Constantina?

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: 'Tis she. O partial heavens! but yet it is not,
'Tis not long since I left my sister safe
With in her chamber, and in another habit —
By all the powers 'tis she — I do profane
The gods; it is not she, it is not. — once more.
The twins of Leda were not half so like.
I'll be resolved immediately.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.l: Good m. justice,Exit.
I pray you hear me. As we did dance even now
In your North field, we found this gentlewoman,
Lying all along (As to say) even quite dead,
And this her husband with his naked sword
Standing hard by her.

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: Another riddle yet.
Her husband? ha? Why is not this Neander
One of the rival's in my daughter's love?

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.l: Ander, or pander, we know not that,
But 'tis her husband, that we're sure of
Is he not Robin?

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.l: I that he is our Edward,
We both were present when they were detracted.

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.l: Subtracted you fool. But as I said before
Seeing him stand so desperately with his sword
We stole behind him, and so caught him.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: A valiant act believe't. Good sir, let's go.

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: Ah Constantina, ah good heart! was this
The journey you intended?

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you —
We shall be poisoned with these women's sighsHe offers to go.
'Tis worse than a German hothouse.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: Anteros
Stay, we will see the end of this.

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: Fie, fie, hell is broke loose upon me: all her furies
Are come at once t'assault me.

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Ah Cleopes! She revives

sp.speaker: Nean:
sp.l: She lives again, oh miracle of women!

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Where art thou Cleopes?

sp.speaker: Nean:
sp.l: O hated name,
Enough t'infect the world, but that it comes
Out of those lips.

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: Speak Constantina.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What have I to do
With light or heaven? I will not live.

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: O me!
She swounds again.

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.l: Why do you rub her head
And face so much, you foolish woman you?
Let me alone, I'll find her wound I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Forbear, or I'll find that swine's face of yours.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I am too bad for hell, they'll not receive me,
They are afraid I should infect those souls,
Those virtuous souls which do inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Nean
sp.l: Art thou not softened yet Neander? Ha?
Hadst thou an heart cut out oth' diamond rock,
Sure this would melt it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O my Cleopes!

sp.speaker: 1 rustic
sp.l: What will you give sir, and I will let you
Shift for yourself?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What thou deservest villain.

sp.speaker: 2 rustic
sp.l: Half part, or else she shall not go.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Take half.
sp.stage: He breaks loose, and beats them out.
sp.l: I will divide my gifts betwixt ye — there.
Thou temple of virtue, fairest Constantina. —

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O I shall die again if I see him.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But will you live if I do presently
Make a divorce betwixt you and Neander?
And place you in the arms of him you so
Love, and adore, your Cleopes?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Thou'rt all divinity, indeed I cannot.
See where Pandora comes; but now I can.
Behold my Lucius.

div.head: Act. 5. Sce. 11.
div.stage: Laurentio, Lucius, Endymion, Pandoura, Isabella, cum caeteris.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Nay, I will still persist to follow thee
Basest of men.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Suffer him;
His tongue has learned the palsy from his hands;
Alas he's old, and must be pardoned for't.
But what imports this multitude? and see Neander
With his boy-bride. Pandora, sweetest lady —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Another tempest! where shall I shelter me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By all the joys in love, by all the sorrows,
By all his roses, and his wormwood, take
thy thoughts from me, and let them doubled fall
Upon my friend Neander. — fairest foul,
Do but contemplate that most curious frame
Of man, in what a pleasing harmony
Nature has married all those provinces
His limbs together: view but his sparkling eye,
And read divinity there; look on his hair,
Survey his face, and fee how majesty
And sweetness there do strive for victory,
And still the issue's doubtful.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Lucius,
Thou shalt not overcome; disguise farewell.
O thou that art the shame of all thy sex,
Fair Constantina, yet not half so fair
As virtuous, here behold thy Cleopes;
Neander's vanished; why do you wonder so?
I do confess I loved that gentlewoman,
And for her love I took on this disguise,
And here for thine I put it off again,
And on my bent knee do beg my pardon
For all the wrong I've done thee

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cleopes!

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: It is a miracle: but the bonds, the living.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O heavens! 'tis he, most happy Constantina!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: My Cleopes? grant me some respite joy
Before thou killest me — o my Cleopes!
Whom do I embrace? into whose arms am I fallen?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O constant virgin!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: But how shall I hereafter
Give any credit to my senses? O
Placenta, courteous midwife, pray thee tell me,
Where am I now? in heaven?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Bridle your passion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Am I myself? or do I dream all this?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Lucius, take truce with wonder, I am Cleopes,
And I do hope though now I wear that name,
As dear to thee as when I heard Neander.
You may remember whenas first the beauty
Of fair Pandora did attract your eyes
To wonder, and to love, that I was then
A busy wooer unto Constantina:
But so it pleased Cupid, that while I
drew out a languishing and lukewarm suit
To her, the vigour of Pandora's beams,
(As doth the sun unto our culinary fire)
Did quite extinguish that same petty flame.
Thinking it vain t'attempt her in that shape,
I presently did take some discontent,
And feigned a journey into Belgia,
And not long after took on this disguise,
And returned hither; where I have remained
Your rival, and capital friend together:
And (Which I wonder at the most) unknown:
You have my metamorphosis. But sweet,
How cam'st thou pray thee, unto Mr. lively?
And by what tricks did he inveigle thee
Unto this contract, since thou didst not know
That Cleopes was there invisible?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My better genius, you shall hear within
The story whole, it is too tedious
To be told here.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: But now Pandora, why
Stand you so dully here, and do not fly
Into his strict embraces, who alone
Loves you, and who alone deserves your love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Do I love her? do I deserve her love?
Hast thou (Sweet friend) for me forsaken her,
Whom thou didst prize 'bove thine own proper soul?
And now hast married her whom thou didst fly?
And all for my sake, and shall I thus repay thee?
But for her love thou never hadst been Neander;
And but for mine hadst been Neander still;
Friend Cleopes, or if thou wilt Neander,
(Under both titles most beloved of me)
Was she all Venus; did each hair of hers
Fetter a love, were there as many Cupid's
That hovered o'er her head, as there be lights
Which guild yond marble roof, by them I swear,
By all that's sacred, by whatever flies
The touch of mortal eye, I swear again,
I would disclaim her and her love for ever.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Troth Lucius, I do pity you, that do
spend so much breath unto so little end,
What need all these deep protestations?
I care not this for all your love, nor yet
For your friend Janus there with the two faces;
Nor do I think ye men.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So quickly?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes.
I do confess I am a woman; see,
Here is the man has won what ye have lost;
Stout soldiers sure, that when the city gates
Were open to ye, durst not enter in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Isabella, 'tis for thy sake I know
That all these miseries do happen me.
(Forgive me good Laurentio) Isabella,
At length I have experience what it is
To love an outside, the mere bark of woman,
And to forsake an inward virtue: but
If once I have thee in possession more —

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Follow me witch, devil, strumpet, prostitute.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ah whither will he drag me? o my heart!

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What have ye done with my dead sister's body?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thy sister's body now has got a soul.
(Oh my sweet Cleopes!) most welcome brother.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: But doth she live then?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: And so happily,
As I have called it impudence to wish
What I do now enjoy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Whom do I see?
My daughter Isabella?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: But is this Cleopes?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I dare not look upon that wronged face.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: It is, and now thy sister's husband.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Brother,
All health, all happiness.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: More than all to you,
Good Cleopes. — but dost thou live, my sister?
Why wast thou dead but now?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Thou shalt hear that
Some other time.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Seest thou that virgin?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes, it is my sister Isabella.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am undone! my father, and my brother.
Sir, I beseech you pardon what my love,
And younger years have trespassed.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Rise my daughter;
Joy will not suffer me for to be angry.
Seest thou that face?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: It is Endymion
My brother. — brother, God save you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Sister!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thy brother? 'tis thy traitor that I mean,
That has undone thee and thy name.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: 'Tis Lucius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you do not hearken to him.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pox upon this honesty,
It will undo us all: 'tis ten to one
But that his tender conscience will persuade him
To pay in the money for all this.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fair soul
Canst thou forgive thy Lucius?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Canst thou love
Thy Isabella?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Give me a man dares ask
That question? Good Laurentio let me crave
Your liking and consent.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Consent? to what?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To marry this your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Marry my daughter?
No perjured wretch.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you grant it.
O Lucius! O happy hour!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thou hast her,
And with her such a portion as shall please thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will not hear of portion, she herself
Is dowry enough to me. — oh Isabella!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: What? Is the player's boy proved woman too?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: I say trouble me not — the mortgage.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And let me have your approbation ▪
In this young gentleman for my husband.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Perhaps sir you may doubt of his estate,
But if you'll credit me, I can instruct you,
I am his father, he mine only son,
And (I do thank my stars) our fortune's are
None of the meanest. Speak sir, will you give
Your daughter here, without a portion?

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: Without a portion? take her what ere thou art
So, so, that care is passed yet, this a little
Help's out with th' other losses.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Master hook,
You shall not frown, since all things here do smile;
Tomorrow I will pay you half your money,
So you will grant me a general acquittance;
'Tis in my power (You know) and I may choose
Whether I'll pay a farthing, but no more,
(There is a thing called conscience within me;
And) you shall have it: therefore be frolic sir.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: Thou art an honest man. Ye are all honest, ye are all honest.

div.stage: Enter liuely having heard the other scene.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: All this while have I
Employed mine cares about this business.
Now show thyself, and of what house thou comest.
All health to this fair company — much joy —
Much happiness — and a young son to you;
Are you at leisure for to kill me yet?
You see I'm come again.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee
Thou instrument of all our good.

sp.speaker: Lively
sp.l: Yes, yes,
I was a fool, knew nothing, knew just nothing,
Could not divine a whit, not tell, not tell,
How this same gear would come to pass, not I;
How do you like your lively now? your lively?

sp.speaker: Hooke
sp.l: We will discourse of that within. Terpander,
Sir will it please you follow? you my son,
Gentlemen you're all my guests tonight . Methinks
I am grown pestilent kind upon the sudden,
The music too, we will be merry, come,
Nay come, come, take me while the humours hot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Love-all, a word: nay troop on, let them troop.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The news?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'faith nothing but to take my leave,
Bid you far well.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why so? I pray thee stay,
You'll in I hope.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What among such a kennel
Of women? no, adieu.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nay prithee go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not for the fairy kingdom.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.l: Mr. Loveall,
Sweet Mr. Loveall.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman, and an elder brother, I am almost choked.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Loveall, oh Mr. Loveall. 'tis utterly against my complexion,
To lie here any longer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Death! our fools,
Our dish of buffles: as I hope to prosper
My thoughts had lost them quite.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I thought not of them.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.l: Good Mr. Loveall are the officers gone?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Anteros, Anteros, is the coast clear yet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But how shall we dispose of them?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: We'd best
Barrel them up and send them for new England.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pox there's fools enough already there.
Let's pickle them for winter salads.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: No;
they are not capable of salt, man; rather
Let's get some broken trumpet, or old drum,
And show them to the people from some strange
Beasts out of Afrique

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Father, my gown is not silk yet.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: A bots on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hark, there's another egg sprung, my shepherd and his fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.l: Loveall, Mr. Loveall, I am of a sanguine complexion.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now all the world! what shall we do with them?
But stay, a word, — perform it, I'll take order[he whispers with Loveall]
To uncase 'em 'To your hands. —
Now quickly Noddle, all is quiet now, —Exit Loveall.
Come Mr. William — not a mouse is stirring —
Safe, safe, all is safe. Ha, he, he.

div.stage: [they all 4 come out at the 4 corners of the stage.]

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.l: I've spoiled my clothes quite, would I had a brush;
How now? we're gulled.

sp.speaker: Wis.
sp.l: Ay, as I am a living soul. — mark the end on't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Who have we here? does his ghost walk?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.l: We are all jeered I perceive it plain now.

sp.speaker: Wis.
sp.p: Who's that? Mr. mongrel? is the scholar alive again? I should have been very melancholy to have been hanged as I am a living soul.

sp.speaker: Nod
sp.l: If I could get my rapier and a brush,[redit in scenam Loveall and placenta with a cudgel.]
I'd steal away.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Would you have a brush? I'll brush ye ye villains,
Nay, Mr. Love-all told me what dusty companions ye were,
And that ye wanted brushing, and how ye bade
Abused my husband, and my daughter, tied them
To a tree, come one your ways, want ye brushing?
Ye rascals, I'll brush you, would ye be brushed ▪She beats them forth
Come on, let's see what covered dish we've here now? She unties them
High day! you lubberly knave; what madam Gillian too?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: What? is she come now to trouble us!
My daughter, I do charge you on my blessing
Look scurvily upon her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Call her not mother darling, but disclaim her,
she is no wife of mine, she does conspire
Against our gentility daughter, and she lies;
Call her the plain old woman, sweet-lips, do;
I'll bear you cut in't, do as your father bids you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But forsooth father, my neckercher is not turned into gold yet.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: They are both mad of a certain.

sp.speaker: Stip,
sp.p: I am a gentleman, and I will be a gentleman, I will enclose, and I will raise rends — I will be a lower-house man, and I will be —

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: An old coxcomb, and you shall be beaten. [she beats him.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But does this stand good in law?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Fear not that; I'll find an old statute for it, doubt it not. You are a gentleman? and you will be a gentleman? I'll make you gentle enough ere I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: And you my sweet lips that will not call me mother, but look scurvily,
Come on your ways I have the common law on my side too for this. [she beats Merda.]

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O mother, I'll never be a gentlewoman more while I live, nor never talk of gold neckerchers, no that I won't truly.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Yes, you shall be a lower-house man, you shall; I'll take you down a pin, you're too high now.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O, o, good wife — oh, o, honey wife.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: You'll in? [exit. Plac. and Merda.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Buz, peace and catch a mouse cry I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is my scholar returned? prithee go in Jack Loveall, I'll change but two words with himExit love.and follow. Well said, nay look not sourly on the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: You have abused me sir, and go to the fence school with me if you dare, or else wrestle a fall with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He give thee satisfaction my rowser
My hit-her better, nay put off these frowns;
What say'st thou to my sister, and the living?
I know you have heard the news from out the cabin,
And you was once a suitor to her; speak,
Will that content thee? come you are not the first
Has got a parsonage with fooling sir,
I will procure it for thee, fear it not:
Nay spare your hat, it will be tedious,
My thanks shall be in oats.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But master Jeoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Follow Jack Loveall in. [exit Ham.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You know I was your master today.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well put the case.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Poor, and ill 'pareled.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Put the case again.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But now you see how strangely altered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Put the case the third time.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you advised of that? I'll ne'er trust winking beast again for your sake, I'll tell you but so. Did you not tell me that Obrum would make me a gentleman? Obrum? Obrum? if Obrum has no better tricks than these, let Obrum keep his tricks to cool his porridge, 'sduds I looked every minute when Obrum would have put a green scarlet suit upon my back like yours, all to be daubed with spingle-spangles ; and in the mean time comes my wife with a black and blue home spun of her own making. Well that same Obrum is a sembling coney catching knave, and I know what I could call you too, but for your whiniard, and your staring goggles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stipes, no more, advance thy duller eye,
Know'st thou what all those blazing stars portend?

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: Ay, ay, by'r lady? how now? 'sduds I think forty obrums have been here, (Master Jeoffry is that Obrum that makes gentlefolks, a tailor?) one Obrum could never have painted them thus.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Peace profane rudeness; what alteration's this?
What mean these bent knees? but are these women?
Am I a convert then? so suddenly?
Surely some power greater than all that sex
Is interposed, veiled in a female outside,
Else how come I so supple jointed, that
Before was stiffer than the Rhodian statue?
There is an homage due, and I must pay't
Spite of my proudest nerves. Most sacred goddess,
Behold a penitent, that falls thus low
Before your feet: as you have shown yourself
More than a mortal, in converting me,
Confirm it by your pardon; 'tis a virtue
No less deserving, and as near to miracle.
And you great monarch, that the world may know
How nigh a kin to heaven and all the gods
You are in blood and power, confute that bold
Erroneous tenet, prove the age of wonders
Still to endure. What I have promised
Unto this shepherd (As a miracle)
To be performed by Obron and this tree,
Do you effect; make us all gentlemen.
Which one kind ray sent from your gracious eyes
Will do, and in that confidence we rise.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
